headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Harris Corporation Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call may be recorded. And now I'll turn the call over to Pamela Padgett, Vice President of In
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Harris Corporation Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call may be recorded. And now I'll turn the call over to Pamela Padgett, Vice President of Investor Relations. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter fiscal 2015 earnings call. I'm Pamela Padgett. And on the call today is Bill Brown, Chairman and CEO; and Mick Lopez, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. And we before ge
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter fiscal 2015 earnings call. I'm Pamela Padgett. And on the call today is Bill Brown, Chairman and CEO; and Mick Lopez, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
And we before get started, a few words on forward-looking statements. In the course of this teleconference, management may make forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements involve assumptions, risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those statements. For more information and discussion of such assumptions, risks and uncertainties, please see the press release and filings made by Harris with the SEC. In addition, our press release and all its teleconference and the related presentation will discuss certain financial measures and information that are non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations with the comparable GAAP measures in respect of our third quarter fiscal 2015 financial results is included on the Investor Relations section of our website, which is www.harris.com. A replay of this call will also be available on the Investor Relations section of our website. 
And with that, Bill, I'll turn it with you.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, thank you, Pam, and good morning. Our third quarter results were in line with our preliminary release issued April 21, which opened our debt financing window for the Exelis acquisition. We had a very successful bond offering, and we are maki
componenttext:
Okay. Well, thank you, Pam, and good morning. 
Our third quarter results were in line with our preliminary release issued April 21, which opened our debt financing window for the Exelis acquisition. We had a very successful bond offering, and we are making progress towards an expected June closing, and we'll discuss this further later in the call. 
So before turning to Slides 3 and 4 of the presentation, I'll point out that we're now reporting on both the GAAP and non-GAAP basis to call out acquisition-related costs separately. And my comments today will be around non-GAAP performance, which excludes acquisition costs.
Third quarter earnings per share was $1.32, and benefited from a lower-than-expected tax rate that added $0.07 per share. Earnings per share also reflected good operating performance, benefiting from lower costs, excellent execution and a favorable product mix in RF communications and Government Communications Systems. 
Operating margin was 100 basis points higher than in the prior year, even with higher R&D investment, which was up 8% in the quarter, with some of the increase due to timing between the third and fourth quarters. 
Year-to-date, R&D revenue -- R&D investment is 5.6% of total revenue, with a significant portion being spent in the tactical radio business where we are aggressively developing product offerings for upcoming Army and SOCOM modernization procurements. 
Revenue for the company was $1.19 billion, down 6%, with tactical revenue growth more than offset by further weakness in Public Safety and the significant decline in Integrated Network Solutions, primarily from the wind down of 2 major programs in IT Services. As anticipated, revenue also declined in Government Communications Systems, largely due to a tough prior-year compare related to revenue from commercially hosted satellite payloads.
Orders in the quarter were $1.2 billion, up 
up 9% over the prior year and up 9% sequentially. Both RF Communications and Government Communications orders were up sequentially. 
Tactical Communications revenue was up 6% on continued international strength and some improvement in the U.S. market. Procurement activity picked up in March and April as GFY '15 procurement dollars were allocated to our DoD customers, including SOCOM where we received orders totaling $27 million to continue expanding their wideband networking capability. 
And momentum continues to build for U.S. tactical modernization. Just last week, Harris was awarded a 10-year $3.9 billion IDIQ contract for the Rifleman Radio, with an $800,000 initial order for qualification and test units. The Army expects to begin fielding Rifleman before the end of GFY '17.
The Army also recently kicked off their long-awaited procurement for the manpack. Everything was released in April and was quickly followed up, as well as the first quarterly tactical networking forum, which is intended to provide industry with a greater insight into the Army's upcoming procurement requirements. The final RFP is anticipated before the end of September, with an awarded 2Q GFY '16 and full rate production slated to begin in 4Q GFY '17. Preliminary information from the Army indicates a 10-year multi-award IDIQ contract with a ceiling value between $12 billion and $12.7 billion. 
And at SOCOM, last quarter, we resubmitted our bid on a $390 million handheld portion of SOCOM's modernization program with an award anticipated in September. And just a few days ago, SOCOM issued an RFI for their manpack, which we currently expect will be awarded in the spring of 2016. The total SOCOM modernization procurement, which will eventually include a high-frequency radio, could reach $900 million.
Now winning Rifleman Radio on top of the midtier MNVR radio a few years back, and now having a major procurements underway for both the Army manpack and SOCOM, is the culmination of a multiyear, multipronged effort for Harris. Over the last several years, we've worked hard to ensure Army procurements are open to commercial competition and have more recently pushed for a multivendor versus a single vendor award to ensure a level playing field with the program of record. We invested more in Iraq when the rest of industry was investing less, raising R&D spend by more than 20% through the downturn. And today, we see with one of the best lineups of tactical products and technologies than we've ever had. And with modernization procurements now underway and larger than anticipated, Harris is well-positioned to capture a significant multibillion-dollar opportunity.
We also see continued strength in the international tactical market where our business is now twice the size of our U.S. Tactical business. Recent orders include $25 million and $16 million from 2 NATO countries, highlighting there are broad installed base around the world, allows them to be more competitive than supplying radios to Allied countries where interoperability is a critical element for coalition actions. 
We also received orders of $22 million and $47 million from 2 countries in the Middle East. And from a country in Africa, we received $15 million in the quarter, plus another $74 million following the close of the quarter, to the next phase of modernization, bringing orders to date to $486 million. International market is healthy, and our opportunity pipeline remains solid at $2.5 billion and continues to replenish quickly.
In Government Communications Systems, we continued to build on our strong position with the FAA and received our third major NexGen award, an 8-year $238 million single award IDIQ for the Common Support Services Weather program to design and implement a system to provide real-time weather information across the National Airspace System. 
Also from the FAA, we booked $146 million in follow-on orders under our long-standing FBI program where we provide the ultra-reliable network backbone of the U.S. air traffic control system, connecting 4,500 different sites across the country. 
Our DoD business within GCS continues to ramp with F-35. And our strong intelligence franchise provides a platform for future growth. New classified contract wins in the quarter totaled $133 million, including a 3-year $23 million contract from a new customer for space situational awareness in support of Air Force missions. And also in the intelligence area, Harris was awarded a 5-year $300 million single vendor IDIQ contract to integrate various intelligence systems.
Now I'll turn it over to Mick to comment on segment results and guidance before providing an update on the pending Exelis acquisition. Mick?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. Moving to segment results on Slide 5. RF Communications orders were 395 -- $393 million compared to $405 million in the prior year and revenue was $451 million compared to $457 million last year. Tactical
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. 
Moving to segment results on Slide 5. 
RF Communications orders were 395 -- $393 million compared to $405 million in the prior year and revenue was $451 million compared to $457 million last year. 
Tactical Communications revenue was $356 million, an increase of 6%, while orders were $286 million and about flat from prior year of $285 million. 
In Public Safety, market softness and intense competitive pressures continued. Orders were $107 million compared to $120 million in the prior year and revenue was $95 million compared to $122 million last year. 
Operating income for RF Communications was $151 million. And operating margin was a strong 33.5%, as the result of favorable mix, primarily in international, and from lower costs.
Turning to Government Communications Systems on Slide 6. 
Third quarter revenue was $455 million, down 5% compared to $477 million in the prior year. Higher revenue from the U.S. Navy's Commercial Broadband Satellite program and the NGA's foundation geo and Content Management program was more than offset by lower revenue from space customers and from an NOAA.s GOES-R weather program that's transitioned to and integration and test space. 
Segment operating income was $75 million. And operating margin was 16.4%, reflecting strong program performance and favorable product mix.
Turning to Integrated Network Solutions on Slide 7. 
Third quarter revenue was $299 million compared to $348 million in the prior year, with the decline primarily due to the rolloff of 2 large programs in IT Services. 
Operating income was $12 million compared to $21 million last year, primarily due to the wind down of the highly profitable NNCI contract. 
During the quarter, IT Services was awarded a 10-year $450 million single award IDIQ from the Defense Information Systems Agency to provide systems engineering and program management services to Crisis Management System or CMS, a secured video and voice communications network for senior U.S. government officials. This award extends our 30-year relationship supplying less critical component of our national security infrastructure. 
Also in IT Services, we were awarded a position on the $960 million multi-award IDIQ contract for network-centric solutions to Application Services. 
In CapRock, we strengthened our relationships with 2 long-standing energy customers. In the quarter, we received a $35 million order from a major offshore oil and gas driller for a 4-year extension of services across their fleet and 2 orders totaling $21 million from a leading energy services company, extending services across the United States and international locations.
Turning to Slide 8. 
The company generated free cash flow of $150 million, up from the prior year's $120 million as a result of lower CapEx with the completion of GCS's new engineering facility. 
Our non-GAAP tax rate was 29.9% in the quarter, lower than previously expected due to favorable 2014 tax settlements. As announced on April 21, we increased fiscal 2015 guidance for non-GAAP income from continuing operations per diluted share from a range of $4.95 to $5.05 to a range of $5 to $5.10, and updated revenue guidance from a decline in the range of 1% to 3% to an expected decline of about 4%. Fiscal 2015 non-GAAP guidance does not include any impact from pending acquisition of Exelis. GAAP results will include potential post closing revenue and income from Exelis, increased share count from the transaction and acquisition-related costs that are expected to be in the range of $270 million to $290 million, including $125 million in estimated make whole costs associated with the refinancing of Harris debt.
In RF Communications, to reflect further weakness in Public Safety, we now anticipate revenue to be down 3% to 4% and expect to be at the higher end of our previous operating margin guidance of 30% to 31%. 
In Government Communications Systems, revenue guidance is unchanged at up 2% to 4%, with operating margins slightly higher in the range of 15.5% to 16%. 
In Integrated Network Solutions, revenues now expected to be down 14% to 15% to reflect no improvement in the slow procurement environment for IT Services and an incrementally softer outlook at CapRock due to the impact of lower oil prices on the energy market, and to a lesser extent, in healthcare due to a slower revenue ramp. We now expect fiscal '15 operating margin of about 6%.
Expectations for free cash flow are unchanged at about 100% of non-GAAP net income. The tax rate is now expected to be 30%, which adds $0.05 earnings per share for the full year. 
Back to you, Bill.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Mick. When we began fiscal 2015, we anticipated that the constrained budget environment and slow procurement would create some revenue challenges. In Government Communications Systems, where we are on a path to revenue growth for the fi
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Mick. 
When we began fiscal 2015, we anticipated that the constrained budget environment and slow procurement would create some revenue challenges. In Government Communications Systems, where we are on a path to revenue growth for the fiscal year, our strategy of expanding already strong franchises helped overcome government budget constraints. 
In RF Communications, strength in international tactical markets has continued and we have a healthy set of opportunities. And while it's premature to call a bottom for the U.S. tactical market, we are seeing the back half improvement we expected and the momentum building on the large DoD modernization procurements is encouraging. 
And both the Government Communications Systems and RF Communications bottom line performance is excellent. 
So while we see positive indicators in our 2 largest businesses, our revenue challenges in fiscal '15 have been greater than anticipated in Public Safety and in Integrated Network Solutions. 
In Public Safety, the market is soft and competition is aggressive. We are focused on recovery and making measurable improvements in quality and execution. And we continued to build our leadership team and invest in new products. 
This quarter, we introduced our new x G 15 portable radio, which extends our full suite of product offerings and provides public service workers with P25 capability at a competitive price. We'll continue to focus on execution and delivering innovative products to our customers, which we believe will ultimately bear fruit as the market improves. 
In CapRock, while orders were up 24%, with energy orders up 27% in the quarter, we now expect first half revenue growth to turn into a revenue decline in the back half. Our customers are reacting to the persistently below oil prices and taking actions today that even they didn't contemplate just a few months ago. We are responding by not only working to lower costs, but to also provide technology over improve competitiveness and stickiness of our managed communications offering. 
In 3Q, we launched what we call CapRock 1, a multiband antenna and software that transparently switches between C, KU and Ka-bands to provide the most optimal and cost-effective transport medium and is getting great response in the marketplace.
The acquisition of Exelis builds on the stronger parts of Harris. It is an exciting transformative new chapter for the company. We've now secured debt financing for the acquisition and at very favorable terms, which we've outlined on Slide 10. 
A $1.3 billion variable-rate term loan is in place, which provides us a path for quickly deleveraging post acquisition. And we recently issued $2.4 billion in bonds, a portion of which will fund our redemption of $750 million in existing higher coupon Harris notes to take advantage of low interest rates and to extend maturities. The $2.4 billion in new bonds are at a weighted average coupon of about 3.7%. 
As anticipated, we significantly reduced our weighted average cost of debt, including the variable-rate term loans, to about 3.5%, 240 basis points below our previously weighted average cost of 5.9% and with 2 years longer time to maturity. 
We now expect year 1 net interest expense of $180 million to $190 million. And our balance sheet will retain ample liquidity with about $300 million of remaining cash on hand and an existing revolver of $1 billion.
While we received a second request from the Department of Justice, we don't expect any trust clearance to require the divestiture of any business or asset. The request for additional information is related to intellectual property needed to update the encryption in Skin Guards radios to meet an NSA 2024 requirement for secret communication. The Army is considering whether to upgrade the encryption capabilities of these older radios. And much of the information requested is intended to help determine if the Army has all intellectual property it would need to enable other companies to compete for that encryption modification work. We anticipate resolving these concerns promptly. 
The Exelis shareholder vote has been set for May 22, and we continued to expect the transaction to close in June. Integration planning is well underway, with a full time, highly experienced team led by Sheldon Fox, Group President of Government Communications Systems. Sheldon is a 31-year veteran of the government market, with deep experience in key areas where Exelis and Harris have complementary businesses, such as in space and intelligence, advanced weather systems and air traffic management. And of course, I am personally deeply involved and will spend a significant amount of my time over the next several years to ensure we capture the full value of this acquisition.
Since announcing the acquisition, the additional work we've done has only given us more confidence in delivering the previously estimated savings of $100 million to $120 million, which you'll remember is net of what flows back to our government customers. We are working hard to accelerate synergy capture and be at a running start on day 1 following the close. 
And with that, I'd like to ask the operator to open the lines for questions.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Carter Copeland of Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Carter Copeland of Barclays.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick ones. First, on the CapRock decline. I know last quarter, you had sort of outlined that you were protecting for weakness in that market, but not really knowing how to size it just yet, but obviously, we are a quarter on now. What so
componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones. First, on the CapRock decline. I know last quarter, you had sort of outlined that you were protecting for weakness in that market, but not really knowing how to size it just yet, but obviously, we are a quarter on now. What sort of declines are you expecting now at this point? And do you think you'll hit a sort of a run rate decline by the end of the year that levels off? And how should we think about, how much of that is price versus volume? And is there any EBIT related impacts from unsold bandwidth that you can't sell on some of the current contracts right now? How should we think about the weakness there?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me sort of describe what's happening at CapRock and then come back to your question about the bandwidth, unsold piece of bandwidth. I mean, I think we had a really good start to the year, frankly, in the CapRock business. Revenue in the first hal
componenttext: Yes. Let me sort of describe what's happening at CapRock and then come back to your question about the bandwidth, unsold piece of bandwidth. I mean, I think we had a really good start to the year, frankly, in the CapRock business. Revenue in the first half was up sort of in the 3% to 4% range, double-digit, low double digits on the commercial side, somewhat weak on the government side, but overall, up 3%, 4% in the first half. And we are pretty pleased with what was happening in the maritime space. And frankly, in the energy side, the orders in the last 2 quarters were quite good and surprisingly good, up about 25% in Q2 and again a little bit better then in Q3. We do see revenue deteriorating sequentially and year-over-year in the third quarter and we expect that to continue, Carter, into the fourth quarter as well. It will be down probably double digits in the fourth quarter on the energy side. We do see CapRock as a whole being flat to down for the year and down in the back half. With oil that's now sitting in the $50 to $60 per barrel range, I think customers today continued to react quite aggressively to what's happening in the global oil markets are trying to anticipate where pricing is going to be. They're taking very, very aggressive actions. And like I said in my remarks, somewhat unpredictable as where we were and what they were going to do back in early part of February. They're doing a lot of restructuring. Capital spending is coming down. They're parking maybe scrapping some rigs, delaying the awards and acceptance of new rigs. And that's certainly having a pretty big impact on our business. And when we look at what's happening in this downturn versus last several downturns in this global oil market, we see rig count down about 30% by the end of March. I would say we are maybe a little bit half -- a little beyond halfway through the downturn, so we do expect further erosion. We do expect it's going to carry into '16 and be a tough '16 for us. We think the road here is going to be slow in terms of stabilization and a long recovery. But I would say for CapRock as a whole, recall we've talked about the size of our energy business at about $400 million, that's about 8% of total Harris as we speak today, even smaller when we combine it with Exelis. So it's not a big part of the company, but we do expect further pressure in the fourth quarter and the next year on the energy side and that's going to drag down CapRock. Now in terms of the bandwidth, fortunately, we do see quite aggressive growth in the maritime space, particularly in the cruise industry, and that's offsetting some of the pressure that we are seeing in the energy space in some of the bandwidth that we've procured for the energy side.

componenttext: We're not going to call '16 yet, but we do see '16 being softer than we're seeing right now on '15, Carter.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a quick follow-up, just to switch gears quickly on the Exelis synergies you briefly mentioned. You talked about accelerating the synergy capture there on the $100 million to $120 million. Now that you've had a couple of extra months to
componenttext: Okay. And then just a quick follow-up, just to switch gears quickly on the Exelis synergies you briefly mentioned. You talked about accelerating the synergy capture there on the $100 million to $120 million. Now that you've had a couple of extra months to go through this, do you think there's upside to that number over time or any color in the work you've done and identifying and kind of sizing those opportunities?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Carter, no more color today. We still feel very comfortable at that $100 million to $120 million by year 3 net of what's going to be flowed back to our government customers. We are working hard at it. And we're doing a lot of pre-close planning independen
componenttext: Carter, no more color today. We still feel very comfortable at that $100 million to $120 million by year 3 net of what's going to be flowed back to our government customers. We are working hard at it. And we're doing a lot of pre-close planning independently on our own with some outside advisers in a clean room type approach. We do expect to be running at this at closing. And we want to pull forward as much as we can, but no more color today. We are working right now and just getting to a close.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Noah Poponak of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Noah Poponak of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, can you just go back to that detail you were providing on the second DOJ request? And it sounded like they are talking about a technology upgrade and checking if they have a certain round of IP. I guess that would happen if they did want to do that
componenttext: Bill, can you just go back to that detail you were providing on the second DOJ request? And it sounded like they are talking about a technology upgrade and checking if they have a certain round of IP. I guess that would happen if they did want to do that and they didn't have enough IP, like can you maybe just a little more detail on how concerning that is to you or not?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I can't really give a lot more detail on this call. There has been -- as you would expect, there is active conversations going on with the DOJ and this could go in a variety of different ways. I think a couple of things I would say, and not to just reiter
componenttext: I can't really give a lot more detail on this call. There has been -- as you would expect, there is active conversations going on with the DOJ and this could go in a variety of different ways. I think a couple of things I would say, and not to just reiterate what I said in my prepared remarks, but I think the good news is that it is narrowly contained in the tactical radio side. It specifically relates to IP and ownership rights for IP. It does not and we don't believe it will require any divestiture of businesses or assets. So we think we can get our arms around the concern in this issue relatively quickly. And we're working in providing the DOJ the necessary information that they require to work through and resolve this question that they happen to have. And we'll have more to say over the coming weeks as we take this issue forward to DOJ, but nothing -- I can't really speculate on what the outcome or solution may be here on this call.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could they just require you to give IP to the Army or could it be that simple?
componenttext: Could they just require you to give IP to the Army or could it be that simple?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: There could be a variety of responses. We -- certainly, that could be one, but there is -- I won't even speculate as to where they want to go in terms of addressing their particular question given that it's a very active conversation that's happening toda
componenttext: There could be a variety of responses. We -- certainly, that could be one, but there is -- I won't even speculate as to where they want to go in terms of addressing their particular question given that it's a very active conversation that's happening today with the DOJ. I don't think I can provide any more color to that, Noah.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. In the Legacy business with -- when we look at before you're layering in some of the new business you're winning in the domestic tactical radio market with DoD, how do we think about how much of what you have today you'll still have 2, 3, 4 years do
componenttext: Okay. In the Legacy business with -- when we look at before you're layering in some of the new business you're winning in the domestic tactical radio market with DoD, how do we think about how much of what you have today you'll still have 2, 3, 4 years down the road when you're also layering in all of this new business versus how much of what you have today is replaced by that new business?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: There are certainly going to be some replacement of current business, but I think it's on the margin frankly that's going to happen over a long period of time, Noah. Keep in mind that all of the radios that are today in DoD inventory, it's less than 10%,
componenttext: There are certainly going to be some replacement of current business, but I think it's on the margin frankly that's going to happen over a long period of time, Noah. Keep in mind that all of the radios that are today in DoD inventory, it's less than 10%, maybe 5%, 6% that are wideband capable. So I think it's a long-term path to replace all of those narrowband radios with wideband radios. And I think that's going to happen over multiple years, not multiple quarters.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then anything you can tell us about Rifleman, I guess, in terms of trade in your bid? And how we can think about margins on new business revenue compared to the current margins at RF?
componenttext: Okay. And then anything you can tell us about Rifleman, I guess, in terms of trade in your bid? And how we can think about margins on new business revenue compared to the current margins at RF?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Noah, I really like the position that we're in today. It's something that didn't happen overnight. It happened over multiple years in both ensuring competition was -- it was open to competition. We could compete for those procurement dollars that we
componenttext: Well, Noah, I really like the position that we're in today. It's something that didn't happen overnight. It happened over multiple years in both ensuring competition was -- it was open to competition. We could compete for those procurement dollars that we invest and had a radio that met the requirements. In fact, was in some ways more advanced than we were the program of record was at the time in which is which caused some change in the competitive landscape for the Rifleman Radio. We are bidding on commercial terms. It's a competitive procurement. It looks much the same as what happened on the Fisher program a number of years back where it was a IDIQ shootout between us and Telus on task orders. It was completely commercial. Initial awards for Rifleman are going to be LPTA, Low Price Technically Acceptable. And over time, there will be some best value type opportunities for us. What's interesting is that the ceiling value is quite high at about $3.9 billion. And in a Rifleman, the RFP, it was both the single channel Rifleman, but also they started to introduce a 2-channel handheld over time. And how that gets shaped and when that's being brought in is still all to be determined. So I like our position. I like our scale. I like the advantage our technology brings. I like the fact that our commercial model allows us to continue to invest to advance our technology and compete with whatever we happen to have. And our margins today on the handheld look great. And it's even after competing with players around the world on the program. So I kind of like what we have in the outlook for our business, both top line and bottom line.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pete Skibitski of Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pete Skibitski of Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hey, Bill, you sort of anticipated my question on U.S. DoD radio volume and whether or not we were kind of a trough in fiscal '15. The volumes have come down quite a bit. You've won Rifleman. You mentioned MNVR. What else are you kind of looking for to ki
componenttext: Hey, Bill, you sort of anticipated my question on U.S. DoD radio volume and whether or not we were kind of a trough in fiscal '15. The volumes have come down quite a bit. You've won Rifleman. You mentioned MNVR. What else are you kind of looking for to kind of signal we are at a trough? I mentioned the SOCOM, when if you could get that would help quite a bit. But are you worried about ACR next year? What else is kind of going into your thinking?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we feel really good about where we're at, Pete, frankly. And just the fact that the Rifleman IDIQ was awarded last week, and I don't think you've ever heard me say sooner than we expected when I talk about government contracting, and it was sooner t
componenttext: Well, we feel really good about where we're at, Pete, frankly. And just the fact that the Rifleman IDIQ was awarded last week, and I don't think you've ever heard me say sooner than we expected when I talk about government contracting, and it was sooner than we expected by a number of months, and that's because of the changes that happened in the industrial base for the Rifleman Radio, I believe. And it came in a lot higher than we thought. And it's encouraging to see the manpack moving forward. It's encouraging to see the SOCOM modernization moving forward and an RFI out last week for the man part manpack's part of SOCOM, so we're starting to see some movement here. And as I said in my remarks, it's tough to call the bottom. We are seeing both sequentially and year-over-year improvement in the second half, and we expected that would happen in the beginning of the year. If you look at the budgets, there's still a lot going on in DC. The outlook, I think, it looks good for us. It's improving a little bit. What's happening coming out of the house warm services, we see what the markup is that they cannot with last week I guess was early last week, which shows the base at the BCA cap, but a substantial amount of OCO funding in total at $585 billion, in line with where the President happens to be. And if it follows the way we seen the past years in terms of how that budget flows down to tactical radio line items, I think if it follows that, it will follow where the President happens to be. And the President put in a budget for which would showed good funding, good funding growth on the MNVR product, good funding growth on HMS and good funding increases in the other services. And I think that's quite encouraging. For the HMS, which is the Rifleman and the manpack, there is a lot of unspent funds still available. And as you look at the ramp, it ramps relatively quickly over the next 2 to 3 years to close $0.5 billion a year, again, in the President's budget, a couple of years out, which I think is quite encouraging. So you put the fact that the Army's moving forward with the budget, next to the fact that the funding appears to be ramping pretty nicely over the next 3 or 4 years, you put those 2 pieces together and I think the outlook for our business in DoD is pretty positive.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Very helpful. I wanted to ask another question about the transaction. You guys don't paying off roughly half the debt you incurred over 5 years, is that still the plan?
componenttext: Okay. Very helpful. I wanted to ask another question about the transaction. You guys don't paying off roughly half the debt you incurred over 5 years, is that still the plan?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our plan is to go from 2.9x to 1.5x net leverage over the next first 3 years, which would require us to pay a makedown $2 billion of debt roughly plus or minus in the first 3 years.
componenttext: Our plan is to go from 2.9x to 1.5x net leverage over the next first 3 years, which would require us to pay a makedown $2 billion of debt roughly plus or minus in the first 3 years.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, got you. And then on the acquisition-related costs, roughly $280 million. So are those all cash, first of all? And about $125 million of that in the fourth quarter on the refinancing costs?
componenttext: Okay, got you. And then on the acquisition-related costs, roughly $280 million. So are those all cash, first of all? And about $125 million of that in the fourth quarter on the refinancing costs?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Most of those are cash, $125 million as we stated make make whole for the $750 million of refinancing. There is approximately another $75 million, which is going to be acquisition-related, with Exelis, severance fees, lease cancellations, restructuri
componenttext: Yes. Most of those are cash, $125 million as we stated make make whole for the $750 million of refinancing. There is approximately another $75 million, which is going to be acquisition-related, with Exelis, severance fees, lease cancellations, restructuring of the sort. The remainder is basically deal costs and financing for the bridge and some negative carry, so most of it is cash.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I would also just say that again, it all presumes at June close. We expect the June close, but that all presume is June closing.
componenttext: And I would also just say that again, it all presumes at June close. We expect the June close, but that all presume is June closing.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Gautam Khanna of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question is from Gautam Khanna of Cowen and Company.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, could you comment on what effect, if any, the strengthening dollar and softer oil prices have on your foreign pipeline in RF?
componenttext: Bill, could you comment on what effect, if any, the strengthening dollar and softer oil prices have on your foreign pipeline in RF?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the price of oil, I think it's a bit hard to say. We haven't seen any significant impact at the moment. We do know that more than half of our international pipeline is in the Middle East, northern Africa region. What's interesting is that even though t
componenttext: On the price of oil, I think it's a bit hard to say. We haven't seen any significant impact at the moment. We do know that more than half of our international pipeline is in the Middle East, northern Africa region. What's interesting is that even though there is the price of oil has come down quite precipitously over the last 6 to 9 months, that piece of our pipeline on a percentage basis and a dollar basis is where it was 6 to 9 months ago even after booking a number of large orders, including one that came out just a couple of weeks ago in Africa at $74 million. So we feel pretty good about that. We do know that we have a large opportunity coming over the next several years in Iraq. We do know that the country doesn't have a lot of foreign currency reserves. Oil is going to be a bigger impact on Iraq, but likely, fortunately, it's sort of underpinned by U.S. funding, both in the fiscal '15 budget, as well as in the fiscal '16 proposed O.C. elders funding for the Iraq train and equip funding. So that does backstop was a little bit for oil-related concerns in Iraq. So overall, not a concern today. It doesn't mean that it won't comment front of us over the next number of quarters. On FX, I think you know we do business around the world in U.S. dollars. And we compete against, in some markets, euro-based competitors. So over time, that could have some marginal effect if we don't adjust price and if the euro doesn't improve. We see that in the last couple of weeks the euro getting a little bit better. But today, no big effect. But again, if the dollar strengthens considerably from where we are today, there could be some effect that we have to react with pricing.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just 2 others. I mean, given the book-to-bill at Tactical are at was under 1 again. I just wonder, can you give us a sense for what you anticipate over the next couple of quarters? You mentioned the improved procurement environment since the qua
componenttext: Okay. And just 2 others. I mean, given the book-to-bill at Tactical are at was under 1 again. I just wonder, can you give us a sense for what you anticipate over the next couple of quarters? You mentioned the improved procurement environment since the quarter. What should we expect book-to-bill to trend at in the next couple of quarters?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So year-to-date book-to-bill was about 1.87. So I think given the current U.S. government environment and some of the pretty healthy shipments we've made internationally I think it's a pretty good result, that 0.87 in order for numbers for the year and ou
componenttext: So year-to-date book-to-bill was about 1.87. So I think given the current U.S. government environment and some of the pretty healthy shipments we've made internationally I think it's a pretty good result, that 0.87 in order for numbers for the year and our guidance for the year, book-to-bill of the year needs to come in pretty close to 1. So we do know that there is some big opportunities that are coming our way in Q4 and good again to point out that we received a pretty good-sized award on the international side, $74 million is a week or 2 ago and I tink that's a good positive sign. From I'm not sure I'll go into fiscal '16, but certainly, as we look out through the balance the year, which is only a couple of months away to the end of our fiscal year, we are down year-to-date about 1% on tactical revenues. Obviously the be up low single digits, call it a couple of percent. We do need to see some good growth in the fourth quarter, that's going to come with some good orders at we do expect. Later, and the international side has been trending pretty well. It's up high single digits. We expect it to be up high single digits for the year, which means Q4 is going to be about that same level of performance. On the DoD side, it has been softer on a year-to-date basis. We are down sort of in that 20% range. We are guiding to be in our guidance that we expressed a little bit a while ago on where RF as a whole is, embedded in that is DoD down 10% to 12%. And probably on a better set of that, may be down about 10%. That requires Q4 to be quite good. We typically see, Gautam, Q4 being stronger sequentially from Q3. And we saw that last year where Q4 revenues about double where we were in Q3 last year. We did see some positive movement in DoD in Q3 and it was reassuring to be -- to see positive growth after a number of quarters in a row of being down year-over-year on DoD. And I'm also glad to see that the pipeline for DoD is getting a little bit better than we were 3 months ago. Last time we spoke, it was about $900 million or so in size. Today, it's about $970 million. There is more that's weighted towards proposal, closure and finalization. So the nearer-term pipeline is looking a little bit better and it gave us a bit more comfort that Q4 will be better year-over-year and better sequentially than Q3. And we are counting on that to hit the guidance and again come back to a full year of close to a 1 on book-to-bill. I won't speculate at the moment going into fiscal '16. I'll have more to say about that once we closed Exelis and report our earnings in late July.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. One last one. On the environment we're seeing on the jitters programs, can you comment on what you anticipate? I mean, how is this going to drag margins as these programs mature? I presumed much like when the seizure contracts, you'll see substantia
componenttext: Okay. One last one. On the environment we're seeing on the jitters programs, can you comment on what you anticipate? I mean, how is this going to drag margins as these programs mature? I presumed much like when the seizure contracts, you'll see substantial price reductions over time. And I'm just curious, I think Noah asked the question of cannibalization earlier.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd like to maybe if you could probably address not just in terms of the new programs replaced the single champ 117[ph] sales if you in manpack for example, but also just broadly on pricing, are we going to see a big price down on the business, that's goi
componenttext: I'd like to maybe if you could probably address not just in terms of the new programs replaced the single champ 117[ph] sales if you in manpack for example, but also just broadly on pricing, are we going to see a big price down on the business, that's going to take our view on RF tactical margins much lower than where they are today.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: You know, Gautam, this has been over a number of years, a very price competitive market place. And frankly, over the last 3 years since I've been here, the nature of competition, the mix of DoD in international even within international by country is shif
componenttext: You know, Gautam, this has been over a number of years, a very price competitive market place. And frankly, over the last 3 years since I've been here, the nature of competition, the mix of DoD in international even within international by country is shifting around, increasing our systems business, and yet still through all of that, we are sitting here with north of 30% margins in that segment. And even within spending a lot more on R&D and some shifts happening in Public Safety. So overall, we are finding a way to take costs out, preserve pricing and still preserve our position in margins that are north of 30%. So we're doing I think a very good job of managing our cost structure and prudently managing our investment pattern to maintain very strong margin in that segment. I do think that, over time, will it become more price competitive? It is price competitive. The nature of we're compete against may shift a little bit, but the scale advantage we have in our RF facility in Rochester, the ability to drive technology differentiation in our product over time are going to be the deciding factors over time in this business to be able to preserve margins north of 30% for the RF comp segment. So I'm not -- we're not putting our heads in the sand saying that there aren't dynamics happening here, but I am confident in the team's ability to continue to find opportunities to both take costs out, as well as invest in differentiation, to maintain a pricing environment that allows the whole margins pretty strong in that segment.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Josh Sullivan of Sterne CRT.
componenttext: Our next question is from Josh Sullivan of Sterne CRT.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: One of your targets for the Exelis transaction is to achieve $1 billion in free cash flow by year 4. Can you just walk us through the cadence from year 1 to year 4? And maybe what are some of the gating factors just given today's results?
componenttext: One of your targets for the Exelis transaction is to achieve $1 billion in free cash flow by year 4. Can you just walk us through the cadence from year 1 to year 4? And maybe what are some of the gating factors just given today's results?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it starts with -- and it's a very, very high level. It starts with what we believe, our own ability to generate free cash is on a standalone basis. This year, if you look at our guidance, 100% of net income and a center point of our $5 to $5.10 earn
componenttext: Well, it starts with -- and it's a very, very high level. It starts with what we believe, our own ability to generate free cash is on a standalone basis. This year, if you look at our guidance, 100% of net income and a center point of our $5 to $5.10 earnings per share, our free cash will be just mathematically is in the $530 million range. Where Exelis has been guiding for calendar '15 is in the $250 million to $275 million range is what they've guided towards. So you just put those 2 numbers together and you're about $800 million on a pro forma basis just putting 2 companies together. You then add on top of that net synergies. And again, we are expecting $120 million net by year 3. You roll that it on an after-tax basis and add in working capital improvements, capital efficiency, perhaps a modest adjustments over time in the cash pension costs, and you start to approach $1 billion by year 4. And that's what we expect and that's what we communicated back in early February.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then in the public safety business, is the pressure more on market demand or increased competition? And then is that competition coming from existing or new entrants?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then in the public safety business, is the pressure more on market demand or increased competition? And then is that competition coming from existing or new entrants?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there is a lot of shifts happening in that Public Safety space. There is some consolidation. There are some shifts happening in technology. And we have a very large competitor who is very focused, very aggressive and in a market that's flat to down
componenttext: Well, there is a lot of shifts happening in that Public Safety space. There is some consolidation. There are some shifts happening in technology. And we have a very large competitor who is very focused, very aggressive and in a market that's flat to down a little bit. So those are the dynamics that are happening in this particular market space. We compete in the North American LMR market, that's where we're at. A big competitor has more of a global perspective in terms of their footprint around the world. The market is soft. It is very competitive. I do think that we've had internally within Harris some executional challenges, which we're quickly working to solve. They're not going to solve themselves over the course of a number of months or quarters. It's going to take some time, but we're really focused on this. And we are seeing execution slowly improving. We do see quality improving. We do see customer satisfaction coming back up. We're making progress in developing and expanding our product offering. Our team, our leadership team is getting better. So overall, I see us improving. And you'll start to see the benefits of those investments and performance showing through the markets starting to come back. Longer-term, we will see some growth in this marketplace. More than half of the market is analog that will go digital. We do know over the longer period of time, the market will shift to LTE. It's good to see that first net with the spectrum auctions has been well-funded. It's a well more than $7 billion rates in margin. I know it's going to happen overtime. It's not going to be the next 2 to 3 years, but beyond that, there's going to be an impact on Harris Corporation. And I think we'll be prepared and well-positioned to compete as that market shifts to LTE. So those are the dynamics that are really happening in the North American space that we are faced with and we'll start to see some improvements over time.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one last one. within IT Services, are there any other large holes in the tent such as the MCI contract over the next 12 months that we should just should keep our eye on?
componenttext: Okay. And then just one last one. within IT Services, are there any other large holes in the tent such as the MCI contract over the next 12 months that we should just should keep our eye on?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, NMCI was a pretty long and tall pole in a tent. And it was the vast majority profit in the IT space. And as you know, we compete and win it at very low margins or it was going to go away. And unfortunately, it went away. We have no more revenue or p
componenttext: Well, NMCI was a pretty long and tall pole in a tent. And it was the vast majority profit in the IT space. And as you know, we compete and win it at very low margins or it was going to go away. And unfortunately, it went away. We have no more revenue or profit coming in IT Services from NMCI, but we do still see the year-over-year impact. And as we look over the next couple of quarters or year, there's no single big IT service profit generator that looks anything like NMCI.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Chris Quilty of Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question is from Chris Quilty of Raymond James.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think you guys wrapped up the draft RFP for the manpack program late last month. Were there any surprises, puts or takes on that process in terms of specifications or requirements?
componenttext: I think you guys wrapped up the draft RFP for the manpack program late last month. Were there any surprises, puts or takes on that process in terms of specifications or requirements?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think the -- what the Army is doing I think is prudently drafting objective and threshold requirements that allows a vibrant competition to occur on the objective requirements and incentives over time to invest a company's own dollars to improve the
componenttext: No. I think the -- what the Army is doing I think is prudently drafting objective and threshold requirements that allows a vibrant competition to occur on the objective requirements and incentives over time to invest a company's own dollars to improve their offering to hit the threshold requirements over time like lower weight. They are particularly interested in. There's a number to mention, it's heat, it's range, a lot of things, but weight is a very, very important factor. The objective requirement, if I remember right, was at 14.6 pounds, but clearly, they want it to be a lot less than that[ph]. And this is been something we are laser focused on and have been working on for a couple of years. And we do see opportunities to take weight down pretty substantially over the near-term and go below the objective requirements and actually perhaps even get better than some of the threshold requirements for weight. So no big surprise. One of the, I guess, maybe a surprise was on the size of the ceiling value on the IDIQ at $12 billion to $12.7 billion. It's way above that what we had -- what we were thinking. And of course, it includes services and spares, sustainment costs and a bunch of other things that are well beyond, I think, the opportunities set in front of Harris. But still at that north of $12 billion is quite an impressive top line ceiling value number for the manpack, Chris.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. And just to quantify, with the Rifleman program, that was originated as a Army program. When you look at the value of that contract, does that expand beyond the Army in terms of other services? And I guess the same for the manpack because, right
componenttext: Got you. And just to quantify, with the Rifleman program, that was originated as a Army program. When you look at the value of that contract, does that expand beyond the Army in terms of other services? And I guess the same for the manpack because, right now, you've got customers at the SOCOM, Navy, Air Force buying manpack, and I believe those are funded separately.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. In fact, we -- interestingly, the manpack, the multichannel manpack that was developed to compete for Army procurements is being sold outside of the Army within DoD first. And we'll sell the manpack within the Army, if provided we win a position on t
componenttext: Yes. In fact, we -- interestingly, the manpack, the multichannel manpack that was developed to compete for Army procurements is being sold outside of the Army within DoD first. And we'll sell the manpack within the Army, if provided we win a position on the IDIQ, over the next several years. So we are already selling the MCM outside of the Army. On the Rifleman, it's starting off as a single channel radio, but interestingly, SOCOM is a 2-channel radio. And I would expect that as the Army introduced a potential 2-channel into the Rifleman competition, that whatever is being sold into SOCOM could eventually work its way into regular Army over time. And I see more of that shift happening as opposed to from Army out, at least from the way I would see it today.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And so to clarify those changes or increments would be inclusive of the $3.3 billion to $3.9 billion contract as it stands today?
componenttext: And so to clarify those changes or increments would be inclusive of the $3.3 billion to $3.9 billion contract as it stands today?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: My understanding is, at that ceiling value of $3.9 billion of the Rifleman, it would include a transition to a 2-channel over time. But again, what the acquisition objective is going to be restated to be, what's the mix of a single channel, 2-channel, is
componenttext: My understanding is, at that ceiling value of $3.9 billion of the Rifleman, it would include a transition to a 2-channel over time. But again, what the acquisition objective is going to be restated to be, what's the mix of a single channel, 2-channel, is still to be determined. And we'll know more about that as the Army really starts to rethink the way they want the network to be given a lot of technology changes. I think the same thing is probably going to happen on manpack. I guess when a step back and I look at the size of where the Rifleman is, they're almost $4 billion. And the size of manpack at north of $12 billion, so $16 billion to $17 billion were the ceiling value between these 2 contracts, it's far above, I think, the opportunities set over 10 years for Harris. Another way to look at this is this just looking at what's the President's budget 4, 5 years out, close to $0.5 billion per year for HMS, which is Rifleman and manpack, if you just take that over 10-year basis, $5 billion in terms of opportunity set, that's sort of in line with what we had thought before about the opportunity for Harris in terms of HMS, both manpack and Rifleman. And then, again, that's sort of the speculation on my part, but that's the way I would look at sizing the overall opportunity for the company.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you haven't mentioned it in a while, but you've also seemed to have made some good progress with regard to some of the airborne programs that are all going getting reorganized.
componenttext: Okay. And you haven't mentioned it in a while, but you've also seemed to have made some good progress with regard to some of the airborne programs that are all going getting reorganized.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we have a fantastic offering in the STC -- STT, the small tactical terminal, with bias Sat, which has Link 16 and UHF, VHF capabilities. And the team at GCF is doing a very good job in selling that product. While the Army's evaluating whether t
componenttext: Yes. Well, we have a fantastic offering in the STC -- STT, the small tactical terminal, with bias Sat, which has Link 16 and UHF, VHF capabilities. And the team at GCF is doing a very good job in selling that product. While the Army's evaluating whether the move forward with what they're calling assault in the small airborne Link 16 terminal composition. I think they are supposed to decide sometime this summer which will have link 15 with SRW in it, and that we'll have a play in that if the Army goes in that direction and that's still to be determined. Now the other 1 that's sort of a the drawing board is saner, which is a Small Airborne Networking Radio which is SRW W and W, C and that, I think the Army still evaluating that. I think I saw on the President's budget, I don't know if it's in the house services markup, but a small amount, like $6 million, to push forward that competition on saner. You will see when the budgets are actually set if that's happening. But if there's a small amount of money, that will be an encouragement that the Army is moving forward putting SRW and WNW into a saner product for the Airborne side. And if that happens, I do think that we are going to be very, very well-positioned to compete there. And also, quite frankly, with Exelis, with the to a 1 project that they have, there is an opportunity to actually put some of our own technology into that box, if you will, and offer greater capability for the airborne tier as we combine ourselves with Exelis. So I think there's a lot of different ways of looking at how we might be able to extend our strong presence on the ground to the airborne tier.

componenttext: I don't think that they're going to be billions of dollars. I don't know the exact number, Chris. Last I've seen was, SANR was sized at something like $600 million and salt was sized at something like $200 million, but it could grow over time depending upon the platforms that gets put on. So could it be $1 billion? Maybe, but again, I think we need to wait until we see exactly how the Army wants to move forward with those 2 programs.
