headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pam, and good morning. Our fourth quarter was productive for Harris, and we ended the year with solid results. Harris' stand-alone revenue and earnings per share met expectation, and free cash flow was stronger than expected at 119% of non-GAAP
componenttext:
Thank you, Pam, and good morning. Our fourth quarter was productive for Harris, and we ended the year with solid results. Harris' stand-alone revenue and earnings per share met expectation, and free cash flow was stronger than expected at 119% of non-GAAP net income, exceeding our goal of 100%.
A significant accomplishment in the quarter was closing the Exelis acquisition on May 29, a bit sooner than expected, and allowing us to accelerate a few key actions and speed up the pace of integration. On the day of closing, we consolidated headquarters activities with Harris and Exelis. On July 1, we announced our new organizational model, creating 4 market--focused segments and combining the top talent of both companies. And then 2 weeks later on July 15, we announced our intent to close Exelis' Fort Wayne tactical radio facility and consolidate production in our world-class Rochester manufacturing operation. So we're off to our a good start, and we'll provide a little more color on our integration efforts during the call.
At the end of the quarter, we closed on the sale of our commercial Healthcare business [indiscernible] providing the business the domain expertise and leverage to allow it to reach maximum potential. As we've expressed before, the Exelis acquisition provides us the unique opportunity for portfolio-shaping actions and in the context of our now larger combined company, we'll continue to take this -- in evaluating what businesses are strategic and which are better served under a different owner.
Turning now to our financial results on Slide 4 of the presentation. Harris earlier today reported non-GAAP earnings per share of $1.32 in the fourth quarter and $5.14 for the full year, both of which include a $0.09 benefit from 1 month of ownership of Exelis. Excluding the impact of Exelis' operating results for the month of June, non-GAAP Harris stand-alone earnings were $1.23 [ph] in the fourth quarter and $5.05 for the full year with full year revenues down 4%, in line with prior guidance and reflecting good operating performance.
In the fourth quarter, higher revenue and continued margin strength for both RF Communications and Government Communications was more than offset by the anticipated weakness in Integrated Network Solutions.
Orders for Harry stand-alone were $1.28 billion, up 17% over the prior year, and significantly higher in RF Communications and Government Communications. Book-to-bill for the quarter was just above 1 and for the full fiscal year was 0.98.
Strategically, we continue to increase our international footprint and invest aggressively in company-funded R&D to position the company for future growth.
International revenue was up 2% in the quarter and 4% for the year, increasing as percentage of total revenue from 30% last year to 32% this fiscal year. And we increased our investment as a percentage of total revenue to 5.7% per share compared to 5.3% in fiscal '14 and 4% just 3 years ago.
I was particularly pleased with our free cash flow results, coming in about $100 million above what we were guiding on Harris stand-alone due to continued tightening of capital spending and improved working capital performance, including higher accounts payable.
Before turning Mick to go to the details of the financials, let me offer a few high-level comments on the segment. Revenue at RF Communications was up 2%, [ph] driven by a 5% increase in tactical and 4% decline in Public Safety. Within tactical, continued strength in international more than offset the declines in the U.S., which was a little lower than expected as a result of orders from 2 customers totaling $28 million, taking a little longer to finalize [indiscernible] this quarter. The majority is now booked and shipped.
Regardless of the slip, back half [indiscernible] solid 6% growth, with Q4 book-to-bill of 1.1 and 0.9 for the year.
In the international tactical market, highlight was a 5-year $55 million order from Australia for tactical and logistics superport to ensure combat-readiness of our JP2072 [ph] product that we previously shipped, bringing orders to date in Australia to more than $700 million. [ph] This further strengthens our partnership with the Australian Defence Force and helps position Harris for Phase III of the country's multiyear battlefield communication modernization program that represent a $750 million [ph] opportunity, which is outside of our 12- to 18-month pipeline.
In the U.S. tactical market, we saw continued momentum for Army modernization. As you know, early in the fourth quarter, we were awarded 10-year $3.9 billion IDIQ contract for the [indiscernible] and in late July, we completed qualification with the customer. On a much larger manpack program, the final RFP was released on August 3, earlier than the September time frame we previously expected. We did do on 60 days [ph in what would be a very [indiscernible] 10-year $12.7 billion multivendor IDIQ contract. The Army now intends to award up to 3 IDIQ contracts in December, followed by qualification testing in March and customer testing in mid-summer 2016, with full-rate production delivery and start date in the first quarter of our fiscal '18, pretty much as we expected. The published acquisition objective is for 65,000 radios, and I continue to believe that we're well positioned to capture a significant portion of this multiyear, multibillion-dollar opportunity.
And finally, our midtier MNVR radio for the Army completed limited user testing [indiscernible] 15.2 to significant milestone towards full-rate production. [indiscernible] expected to follow with operational test and evaluation at NIE 16.2 [ph] and a full-rate production [indiscernible] September of 2016. MNVR should begin to ramp in fiscal '16, and together with Rifleman Radio, should become a more significant revenue contributor and driving good growth for U.S. tactical in '17 and beyond.
Revenue in Government Communications was up 1% in the quarter and 3% for the year, which is an excellent results given the environment. Major growth drivers for the year include our large classified win in geospatial imagery called Foundation content management continued, ramping of F-35, wireless products, DataComm terminals and highband networking radios for the army and mission radios for the airborne market.
I'd also quickly highlight a new strategic partnership with exactEarth that we announced in Q4. exactEarth is the market leader in satellite-based remote tracking. And in the fourth quarter, we received a $55 million order to place 58 commercially hosted payloads on the [indiscernible] to refresh the exactEarth network. This is the same satellite platform that host Aireon and other payloads in which Harris has a prime role, and it's a good strategic point for our team.
Let me now turn over to Mick to provide some greater detail on our fiscal guidance. Nick?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning to everyone. Slide 5 provides a detailed reconciliation of GAAP, non-GAAP and to Harris' standalone non-GAAP earnings, highlighting $281 million in onetime deal and integration costs in FY '15, which is in line with the $
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning to everyone. Slide 5 provides a detailed reconciliation of GAAP, non-GAAP and to Harris' standalone non-GAAP earnings, highlighting $281 million in onetime deal and integration costs in FY '15, which is in line with the $270 million to $290 million in our prior guidance. We also incurred additional charges in Q4 of a net $32 million for restructuring, other items impacting Harris stand-alone business, with the largest part being an intangible impairment in Integrated Network Solutions for the NMCI contract. Excluding $0.09 per share contribution from Exelis in Q4, Harris' full year EPS was $5.05.
On Slide 6, we provide further detail on our ending cash balance and capital expenditure, which at $148 million for fiscal year '15 include $4 million [indiscernible]
Our tax rate for the quarter and the year was as expected, ending the year with a non-GAAP tax rate of 30.2%. The favorable fiscal '15 rate, which we don't expect to repeat in fiscal '16, resulted from foreign tax credits, tax credit and other fiscal '14 tax settlement.
Moving to the segment results [indiscernible] RF Communications orders in the fourth quarter were $530 million compared to $361 million in the prior year, and revenue was $505 million compared to $493 million last year. Tactical Communications revenue was $366 million, [ph] an increase of 5%, while orders were $402 million.
Public Safety. Orders were $128 million and essentially flat compared to prior year of $129 million. Revenue was $139 million compared to $145 million last year.
Non-GAAP operating income was $159 million, which excludes restructuring charges related to Public Safety. non-GAAP operating margin was 31.6% in the quarter and a strong 31.1%  for the [indiscernible]
Turning to Government Communications on Slide 8. Fourth quarter revenue was $485 million, up 1% compared to $480 million in the prior year. Higher revenue from the Foundation content management program, the F-35 program, Highband Networking Radio for the Army win program, which was partially offset by lower revenue from 2 classified programs and the Navy commercial broadband satellite program. Segment operating income was $66 million, [ph] and operating margin was 13.7% in the quarter and a strong 15.8% for the full year.
Turning to Integrated Network Solutions on Slide 9. Fourth quarter revenue was $289 million compared with $373 million in the prior year, a decline of 23%, primarily due to the wind-down of 2 IT Services programs and continued end market weakness for both IT services and cap.
Non-GAAP operating income was $16 million, [ph] including charges related to restructuring and other items, compared to $33 million in the prior year, primarily due to the wind-down of highly profitable NMCI contract and weakness in commercial health.
Moving to fiscal '16 guidance on Slide 6. Today, we're providing high-level guidance for revenue and EPS with some color around fiscal '16 [ph] based on the legacy businesses [Audio Gap] 
once we have pro forma historical information for fiscal '15 [indiscernible] 4 new segments, we'll provide an outlook for segments as we typically do. We're initiating guidance for GAAP EPS in the range of $5.25, $5.45. And for non-GAAP, in the range of $5.60, [ph] $5.80.
Fiscal '16 non-GAAP EPS excludes [ph] about $60 million to $65 million of integration costs and an $8 million charge related to inventory step-up. It includes about $133 million or about $0.70 per share of Exelis acquisition and tangible amortization.
Fiscal '16 non-GAAP EBIT margin is expected to be in the range of 16.2 to 16.7. Putting aside for a minute cost synergies and the impacts related to the acquisition, guidance reflects segment-level operating margin for legacy Exelis slightly lower than the prior year fiscal performance of about 12.5%. Harris segment-level operating margin is expected to be about flat with the prior year based on legacy RF continued strength similar to the prior year and a more normalized operating margin [indiscernible] of about 15%. And for IT Services and CapRock together, an operating margin of around 9%.
Other P&L guidance details are outlined on Slide 10. I'll start with an update on expected synergies and integration costs. Our integration team has moved aggressively to capture costs synergies is ahead of schedule. As a result, both integration costs and savings are occurring sooner than what we previously expected. We're now on track with the fiscal '16 savings of $70 million, $75 million and expect to be at an annual run rate savings of $120 million as we exit fiscal '17, a year sooner than our original estimate and the top end of the prior range. The $120 million of savings is net of savings that will flow [indiscernible] integration spending was $112 million in fiscal '15, and we expect another $60 million to $65 million in fiscal '16. Total integration costs is now expected to be $150 million. the higher end of our prior range and net of about $25 million of expected reimbursement of the U.S. government, which is not anticipated to begin until fiscal '17. As we move to our greater standardization in process, policies and operations for opportunities [indiscernible] we'll continue to look for opportunities for further integrations.
Revenue is expected to be in a range of $7.67 billion to $7.83 billion, down 3% to 5% on a pro forma basis compared with a fiscal '15 of $8.07 billion. Legacy Harris is expected to be down 2% to 4%. This reflects our initial expectations for Tactical Communications of flat to down slightly with DoD flat to up low single digits and international flat to down low single digits and continuing weakness in Public Safety with a 2 percentage point decline.
In legacy Government Communications, we expect another growth year of up 2% to 3%. For IT Services and CapRock together, we expect revenue to be down 13% [ph] to 15% [ph] as a result of continued end market weakness.
Legacy Exelis pro forma stand-alone revenue is expected to be down 5% to 6% with lower revenue from night vision products, lower revenue from information systems, primarily from 85 million [ph] roll-off of the space [indiscernible] that was lost last October.
Slide 11 provides some additional information including an anticipated [indiscernible] income of about $25 million and [indiscernible] contributions of $173 million this fiscal year. With cash funding remaining roughly flat at $170 million in '17 as a result of pension [indiscernible] provided for under and [indiscernible] 21 legislation. Our unfunded pension liability has declined by about $200 million to $1.9 billion at the end of fiscal '15, principally due to the mandatory funding of the legacy Exelis SERP. The effect of modestly higher discount rate, lower expected return on assets largely offset each other.
So let me turn it back to Bill for a few wrap-up comments before we open the call for questions.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mick. The revenue outlook that Mick just described anticipate budget constraints and the continuing resolution through the end of this calendar year. While the base budget even under sequestered cap is bottoming, it is expected to slowly improv
componenttext:
Thank you, Mick. The revenue outlook that Mick just described anticipate budget constraints and the continuing resolution through the end of this calendar year. While the base budget even under sequestered cap is bottoming, it is expected to slowly improve. The recovery will be gradual with headwinds persisting until budget improve and drive new program funding. In the meantime, we continue to have a robust growing pipeline of opportunities, which is a positive sign for the business.
We also put in place an outstanding team leading the new organization we recently announced. As you see on Slide 12, we've organized into 4 market-focused segments, and each segments' president is a well-seasoned executive in the government market: Chris Young with 33 years; Carl DAlessandro with 31 years; and Bill Gattle [indiscernible] each with 28 years. We've taken our 2 most senior leaders, Sheldon Fox and Dana Mehnert, to focus on driving greater cost and operational efficiencies and reigniting revenue growth across our company. I also believe we've delivered on our promise to put the best of the best from both the Harris and Exelis organization. This is a tough job in the combined company, with nearly half of the top 50 positions now filled by a former Exelis employee. I think the energy and enthusiasm across the entire company is very high with a lot of excitement about our future.
As we entered the fiscal year at a running start on integration and focused on exceeding our synergy goals and driving good earnings growth in '16 with even higher accretion in fiscal '17 and fiscal '18.
Ton conclude, on Slide 13, we're executing very well on all critical integration success [indiscernible] from my deep personal ownership of the integration program to the full-time dedicated team led by Sheldon Fox, that's driving a disciplined process with speed and precision. Through the close oversight of the board and constant communication with employees. The result is that we're now at the high end of our prior range of run rate savings, achieved about 1 year sooner than previously expected, with 90% of the action underpinning the savings completed or in process in just 70 days since we closed.
I'm really proud of what Harris has accomplished this past year, and I'm optimistic and confident about what our new team of over 23,000 dedicated employees can deliver in the future. Together, we're committed to solving our customers' most complex challenges and driving value for our shareholders.
With that, I'd like to ask the operator to open the line for questions.

componenttext: Okay. And could you talk a little bit about Exelis? And you mentioned $170 million minimum payment. This year, I mean, are there -- do you have plans to minimize that cash [indiscernible] any sort of different approach [indiscernible] problem that you can talk about?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we can talk about that. A lot of work has been done on the pension aspect. You may know in 2011, pension was [indiscernible] higher. In 2011, there was an enhanced defined contribution plan that decreased [indiscernible] In '12, we have a lump-sum pr
componenttext: Yes, we can talk about that. A lot of work has been done on the pension aspect. You may know in 2011, pension was [indiscernible] higher. In 2011, there was an enhanced defined contribution plan that decreased [indiscernible] In '12, we have a lump-sum program that decreased [indiscernible] participants. Looking forward, we're taking both off obligations, not just for the pension, but also for some of the other obligations that we have out there. And we're looking at, firstly, derisking the asset portfolio, which is a concern, in order to have more traditional investment match the liabilities, but looking at the obligations, we have ratified the pensioners and future pensioners and be able to offer lump sums. We're looking at traditional approach. So right now, we have a comprehensive study going on. We're using actuaries to determine what's the best course of action forward. But we will take an approach for pension and for the asset and on the liability side. We'll derisk it and to lower the obligations.

componenttextpreview: Yes, personally, it's not [indiscernible] Right now, we're focused [indiscernible] I think we got out of the gate very, very quickly. As we've talked before, the deal was justified on cost savings, not revenue upside. I think we clearly do see revenue opp
componenttext: Yes, personally, it's not [indiscernible] Right now, we're focused [indiscernible] I think we got out of the gate very, very quickly. As we've talked before, the deal was justified on cost savings, not revenue upside. I think we clearly do see revenue opportunities over time. We have a very good team focused on that. We're organized in a way to go after some of the revenue upside by the 4 market-focused segments. I think, importantly, we put one of our most seasoned executives that you know well, Dana Mehnert, on top of Global Business Development. His responsibility is to identify and capture some of those revenue opportunity for the company. So something -- we'll say more about over the course of fiscal '16, maybe not next quarter, but certainly over the course of the year.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, look, we're entering a fiscal '16 where we still have some friction in the system with the government budgets. We do expect ACR to go through of the balance of the year. It could extend beyond that. We'll see over the next several months what's happ
componenttext: Well, look, we're entering a fiscal '16 where we still have some friction in the system with the government budgets. We do expect ACR to go through of the balance of the year. It could extend beyond that. We'll see over the next several months what's happening in D.C., and that does some put challenges in our business especially with Exelis as well. But what we do see, even under sequestered budgets, budgets improving in fiscal '17, '18. We're very, very encouraged that we are seeing some of the modernization spending on tactical radios start to move. I feel good about where we're at Rifleman. I'm really glad to see the menpack RFP come out a couple of days ago. I'm glad to see that they're moving quickly with a 60-day [ph] proposal time period expected to make awards in December, if all things go smoothly in negotiations. So these, I think, are good signs that there's money moving or will move over time, and we feel pretty optimistic that will allow our company to grow, maybe not next year, but certainly in years beyond that.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And maybe just a quick follow-up on the international radio. And can you talk about maybe being flat to slightly down next year? Could you just talk about anything shifting in terms of the regional dynamics? And I know you mentioned an Australia opportuni
componenttext: And maybe just a quick follow-up on the international radio. And can you talk about maybe being flat to slightly down next year? Could you just talk about anything shifting in terms of the regional dynamics? And I know you mentioned an Australia opportunity that comes kind of beyond the pipeline portfolio. But anything that's kind of shifting in the portfolio and the pipeline? And if there's any kind of trajectory to the outlook beyond this year for international radio.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, the international business process, as you know, has been very, very strong. And we ended the year in Q4 very strong. The order were extraordinary. Very glad to see the revenue was up for the full year. It was at the high end of what we were guidi
componenttext: I mean, the international business process, as you know, has been very, very strong. And we ended the year in Q4 very strong. The order were extraordinary. Very glad to see the revenue was up for the full year. It was at the high end of what we were guiding to, nearly 10%. We feel very good about where we ended the year. The pipeline is still [indiscernible] $2.4 billion [ph] last quarter is 2-5 [indiscernible] moves around a little bit time to time, but it's still very solid at $2.4 billion. The shape of the pipeline looks pretty much like it has over the last couple of quarters. More than half of it is in due to the Middle East and Northern Africa, Central Asia. And that does seem to be pretty robust, but we do see in the Middle East countries [indiscernible] which we believe over time are very big for the company. One is in Iraq, and the other is in Saudi Arabia and Iraq. Clearly, the price of oil that's with WTI [indiscernible] $40 [ph] a barrel, that's causing some impact to direct commercial sales. We do know that Iraq sales for us are backed up by U.S. government spending, but there are some new commanders in Iraq, and that's taking a bit slower for some of those sales into Iraq to take place. So Iraq is slipping a little bit. And in Saudi, oil is causing a little bit of a problem there. There's a new leadership team in Saudi Arabia. And certainly, the strike in Yemen is causing some shifting around priorities. Those are the 2 things that have shifted a little bit further to the right. We do see multiyear opportunities in $100 million [ph] both in Iraq and Saudi Arabia. So we feel good about those. Australia is very strong for us. I mentioned in my remarks. It's $750 million phased throughout [indiscernible] opportunity outside of our pipeline, but it's real. We were participating in that, and that's going to end up happening. The longer term, we do see good opportunities in international. As you recall at the beginning of fiscal '15, we started international tactical with relatively modest guidance of up low single digits, and we ended up at about 10%. And I hope, going into fiscal '16, we're being similarly conservative.

componenttext: Yes, that's what we have signaled before. So for the course of fiscal '16 in our current guidance, we've assumed no share buyback.

First of all, the manpack, it's not going to affect our revenue [indiscernible] is what we're thinking at the moment. Based on the schedule as we see it, if you look at just between [indiscernible] manpack, the PBR is about $0.5 million per [indiscernible] HMS program. And over a decade, that's a $5 billion between Rifleman and manpack [indiscernible] best guess on a decade-wide opportunity. Obviously, our revenue is going to depend on our share of both Rifleman and the manpack, but it will affect our fiscal '18 revenue on the manpack price. In terms of cannibalization, we've given a lot of thinking to this, and we believe that it will be mostly incremental for our base business today because it's being bought. The modernization is being bought by different parts of the service than what are buying the replacement Gs and other things. Our sense is that it will be mostly incremental and with not so much cannibalization happening.

componenttext: I think it's 689 [ph] pages either. We had a really, really good [indiscernible] summarize it brilliantly 4 or 5 pages. And I think not much has changed from the very good dialogue action Army during [indiscernible] was a couple of industry days. As you know, [indiscernible] been a lot of active dialogue, a lot of conversation on range, power, link. It was the radio rate, mission rate. [indiscernible] is out. There's been a lot of puts and takes. At the end of the day, the final RFP is in line with what we had expected. Well, I think it's very interesting is that what they're going to do is look for at the time of award, you have to meet certain threshold requirement, and one of which is the 16-pound mission weight. They're going to give you some additional leverage for MUOS and antennas and other things. Then they have a deferred threshold that are requirements to be met by June of 2017, and then there's series of objective requirement that will fold in over time based on how industry evolves to capture some of these opportunities again, like around power, weight, et cetera. So that's the way we see it shaping out. [indiscernible] manpack opportunity is going to be kind of interesting, and I don't know where it ultimately going to go. They're looking for a lower-weight manpack [indiscernible] feature some of the manpack. It could potentially, Chris, be something like a 2-channel handheld that would go to [indiscernible] and maybe over time go into the radio. It's unclear how it's going to evolve over time. And potentially, the way we see 689 pages in a nutshell.

componenttext: Sure. On IT Services, we see down about 15%, and CapRock is [indiscernible] down about 10%. In the CapRock down about 10%, we're seeing the energy business down about 20%. And maybe just to give you a little color on this, back in Q2, Q3, the orders were quite good. We did expect the second half revenue in CapRock to turn down. It, in fact, did. We came in spot on what we thought we would be in terms of the CapRock revenue for the year. We were down in Q4 13%. [ph] Of course, we're seeing now price of oil of just below 45. There's a potential deal with [indiscernible] issue that could drop price of oil down even further. We calibrated [indiscernible] in the CapRock Energy in fiscal '16 down about 20%. And we did see in the past quarter a lot of the major oil companies more restructuring. Rig count is down globally around 36%. We think we've calibrated for current events in CapRock being down about 20% next year. But again, we're watching very, very carefully what is happening to the price of oil, but more importantly, the behavior of our major customers in response to the price of oil, and we're simply reacting to what they're doing.

componenttext: Bill, so I guess, what are the prospects for eventually moving above the $120 million synergy run rate? But I guess, how much of it -- how much is this -- you had identified everything and have just been able to do it much faster versus finding new things or  there being potential to find a lot more opportunity to go even higher than 1 point.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, Noah, our diligence was very, very good. And we're finding that most of the opportunity that we thought we would capture, we have captured, and not much has changed. We knew right out of the gate, the first thing we would act would be
componenttext: Well, first of all, Noah, our diligence was very, very good. And we're finding that most of the opportunity that we thought we would capture, we have captured, and not much has changed. We knew right out of the gate, the first thing we would act would be the public company cost, so we did that right out of the gate. So we knew there was an opportunity in the tactical radio side between the 2 facilities that we have, and we went at that very, very quickly. So most of the things that we have anticipated, we're executing on, as I said, about 90% of the actions that we've contemplated going after 1 20 are completed or in process. So we feel pretty good about that. So as I said, we're 70 days in, and we're at the high end of the range we gave before. As we go forward, we continue to find new opportunities. Will there be some things that work against us? Sure. Without a doubt. But I do believe that we have a good opportunity to continue to drive it above 1 20 today. Our best guess of where we stand today is $120 million.

componenttext: Let me give you some color on that because, first, of the $120 million on the savings, as Mick have mentioned, we reimbursed the government directly immediately [indiscernible] on the cost achieve, it was $130 million to $150 million. headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's really the mix of the rig. When we see rig comes down 36%, that's land. That's near offshore. It's deep offshore, ultradeep. And we're -- because the asset of rigs are so great for the oil companies, they spend [indiscernible] stay in productio
componenttext: Well, it's really the mix of the rig. When we see rig comes down 36%, that's land. That's near offshore. It's deep offshore, ultradeep. And we're -- because the asset of rigs are so great for the oil companies, they spend [indiscernible] stay in production longer. We're more disposed offshore and deep offshore. That's where the revenue happens to be. So even though rig count is coming down like on land a bit more than 36%, not a lot of revenue for CapRock [indiscernible] it's a lot more on the offshore and deep offshore.

componenttext: I see. And then how do you think -- any color or comments you can provide on what potential you see in the Exelis, the legacy Exelis business base margin beyond this year? headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's coming down slightly in fiscal '16 from '15, and that's partly due to revenue coming down a little bit. We're guiding down to 5% to 6%. When we go back to segments of Exelis, we do see [indiscernible] systems and the night vision business both
componenttext: Well, it's coming down slightly in fiscal '16 from '15, and that's partly due to revenue coming down a little bit. We're guiding down to 5% to 6%. When we go back to segments of Exelis, we do see [indiscernible] systems and the night vision business both being down in fiscal '16 about mid single-digits. The IS business, information systems, would be down about 10% with that largest piece of that, 7 or 8 points roughly, that's from the loss of the contract [indiscernible] contract that was lost in October of last year. And we do see the business up mid-teens. That's growing pretty nicely with content with Boeing, with Airbus, with the F-35 ramp, on the 53k, which, of course, they got some good programs there. So when I look at all the pieces of it how they're moving around what's growing, the business does have lower margin. So when that grows faster than others, it does depress the overall margin a little bit. But I do see that there is profit in the margins for the night vision comps. And I do see some softening in that systems business as they transition from what we're production programs to more development programs, and that's sort of a natural transition. So they were down, I think, right about 12.5% pro forma last year, if I remember right, and we're guiding to be slightly less than that in fiscal '16.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Harris Corporation Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call may be recorded.I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Pam Padg
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Harris Corporation Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call may be recorded.
I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Pam Padgett, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter fiscal 2015 earnings call. I'm Pamela Padgett, and on the call today is Bill Brown, Chairman and CEO; and Mick Lopez, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.Before we get st
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter fiscal 2015 earnings call. I'm Pamela Padgett, and on the call today is Bill Brown, Chairman and CEO; and Mick Lopez, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Before we get started, a few words on forward-looking statements. In the course of this teleconference, management may make forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements involve assumptions, risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those statements. For more information and discussion of such assumptions, risks and uncertainties, please see the press release and filings made by Harris to the SEC. In addition, in our press release, on the teleconference and the related presentation, we will discuss certain financial measures and information that are non-GAAP financial measures. A reconciliation to the comparable GAAP measures is included on the Investor Relations section of our website, which is www.harris.com.
A replay of this call also will be available on the Investor Relations section of our website. And with that, Bill, I'll turn it over to you.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pam, and good morning. Our fourth quarter was productive for Harris, and we ended the year with solid results. Harris' stand-alone revenue and earnings per share met expectations, and free cash flow was stronger than expected at 119% of non-GAA
componenttext:
Thank you, Pam, and good morning. Our fourth quarter was productive for Harris, and we ended the year with solid results. Harris' stand-alone revenue and earnings per share met expectations, and free cash flow was stronger than expected at 119% of non-GAAP net income, exceeding our goal of 100%.
A significant accomplishment in the quarter was closing the Exelis acquisition on May 29, a bit sooner than expected, and allowing us to accelerate a few key actions and speed up the pace of integration. On the day of closing, we consolidated headquarter's activities between Harris and Exelis. On July 1, we announced our new organizational model, creating 4 market-focused segments and combining the top talent of both companies. And then 2 weeks later, on July 15, we announced our intent to close Exelis's Ft. Wayne tactical radio facility and consolidated production in our world-class Rochester manufacturing operations. So we're off to a good start, and we'll provide a little more color on our integration efforts during the call.
At the end of the quarter, we closed on the sale of our commercial healthcare business to NantHealth, providing the business the domain expertise and channel leverage to allow it to reach its maximum potential. As we've expressed before, the Exelis acquisition provides us the unique opportunity for portfolio-shaping actions, and in the context of our now larger combined company, we'll continue to take dispassionate view in evaluating what businesses are strategic and which are better served under a different owner.
Turning now to our financial results on Slide 4 of the presentation. Harris, earlier today, reported non-GAAP earnings per share of $1.32 in the fourth quarter and $5.14 for the full year, both of which include a $0.09 benefit from 1 month of ownership of Exelis. Excluding the impact of Exelis's operating results for the month of June, non-GAAP Harris stand-alone earnings per share was $1.23 in the fourth quarter and $5.05 for the full year, with full year revenue down 4%, all in line with prior guidance and reflecting good operating performance.
In the fourth quarter, higher revenue and continued margin strength for both RF Communications and Government Communications was more than offset by the anticipated weakness in Integrated Network Solutions.
Orders for Harris, standalone, were $1.28 billion, up 17% over the prior year and significantly higher in RF Communications and Government Communications. Book-to-bill for the quarter was just above 1 and for the full fiscal year was 0.98.
Strategically, we continue to increase our international footprint and invest aggressively in company-funded R&D to position the company for future growth.
International revenue was up 2% in the quarter and 4% for the year, increasing as percentage of total revenue from 30% last year to 32% this fiscal year. And we increased our investment in IRAD as a percentage of total revenue to 5.7% per share, compared to 5.3% in fiscal '14 and 4% just 3 years ago.
I was particularly pleased with our free cash flow results, coming in about $100 million above what we were guiding on a Harris stand-alone basis due to continued tightening of capital spending and improved working capital performance, including higher accounts payable.
Before turning it to Mick to go to the details of the financials, let me offer a few high-level comments on the segments. Revenue at RF Communications was up 2%, driven by a 5% increase in Tactical and a 4% decline in Public Safety. Within Tactical, continued strength in international more than offset the decline in the U.S., which was a little lower than expected as a result of orders from 2 customers totaling $28 million, taking a little longer to finalize and missing the quarter cut. The majority is now booked and shipped. Regardless of the slip, back half for Tactical came in at a solid 6% growth, with Q4 book-to-bill of 1.1 and 0.94 for the year.
In the international tactical market, a highlight was a 5-year $55 million order from Australia for technical and logistics support to ensure combat-readiness of our JP 2072 phase 2 products that we previously shipped, bringing orders to date in Australia to more than $700 million. This latest win further strengthens our partnership with the Australian Defence Force and helps position Harris for Phase 3 of the country's multiyear battlefield communication modernization program that represent a $750 million opportunity, that sits outside of our 12- to 18-month pipeline.
In the U.S. tactical market, we saw continued momentum for Army modernization. As you know, early in the fourth quarter, we were awarded a 10-year $3.9 billion IDIQ contract for the Rifleman Radio, and on late July, we completed qualification testing with the customer. On the much larger Manpack program, the final RFP was released on August 3, a bit earlier than the September time frame we previously expected, with bids due in 60 days for what will be a very sizable 10-year $12.7 billion multivendor IDIQ contract.
The Army now intends to award up to 3 IDIQ contracts in December, followed by qualification testing in March and customer testing in mid-summer 2016, with full-rate production delivery start dates in the first quarter of our fiscal '18, pretty much as we expected. The published acquisition objective is for 65,000 radios, and I continue to believe that we're well positioned to capture a significant portion of this multiyear, multibillion-dollar opportunity.
And then finally, our mid-tier MNVR radio for the Army completed limited-user testing at NIE 15.2, a significant milestone towards full-rate production. LRIPs are expected to follow with operational test and evaluation at NIE 16.2, and a full-rate production award in September of 2016. MNVR should begin to ramp in fiscal '16, and together with Rifleman Radio, should become a more significant revenue contributor and drive good growth for U.S. Tactical in '17 and beyond.
Revenue in Government Communications was up 1% in the quarter and 3% for the year, which is an excellent result given the environment. Major growth drivers for the year include our large classified win in geospatial imagery called Foundation GEOINT Content Management, continued ramping of F-35, wireless products, SATCOM terminals and highband networking radios for the Army and mission radios for the airborne market.
I'll also quickly highlight a new strategic partnership with exactEarth that we announced in Q4. exactEarth is the market leader in satellite-based remote ship tracking, and in the fourth quarter, we received a $55 million order to place 58 commercially hosted payloads on the Iridium NEXT constellation to refresh the exactEarth network. This is the same satellite platform that host Aireon and other payloads in which Harris has the prime role, and it's a good strategic win for our team.
Let me now turn it over to Mick to provide some greater detail on the results and our fiscal '16 guidance. Mick?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning to everyone. Slide 5 provides a detailed reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP and to Harris' stand-alone non-GAAP earnings, highlighting $281 million in onetime deal and integration costs in FY '15, which is in line with th
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning to everyone. Slide 5 provides a detailed reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP and to Harris' stand-alone non-GAAP earnings, highlighting $281 million in onetime deal and integration costs in FY '15, which is in line with the $270 million to $290 million in our prior guidance. We also incurred additional charges in Q4 of a net $32 million for restructuring and other items impacting Harris stand-alone business, with the largest part being an intangible impairment in Integrated Network Solutions for the NMCI contract. Excluding $0.09 per share contribution from Exelis in Q4, Harris' full year EPS was $5.05.
On Slide 6, we provide further detail on our ending cash balance and capital expenditures, which at $148 million for fiscal year '15 include $4 million from the Exelis.
Our tax rate for the quarter and the year was as expected, ending the year with a non-GAAP tax rate of 30.2%. The favorable fiscal '15 rate, which we don't expect to repeat in fiscal '16, resulted from foreign tax credits, the R&D tax credit and other fiscal '14 tax settlements.
Moving to segment results on Slide 7. RF Communications orders in the fourth quarter were $530 million, compared to $361 million in the prior year, and revenue was $505 million, compared to $493 million last year. Tactical Communications revenue was $366 million, an increase of 5%, while orders were $402 million.
In Public Safety, orders were $128 million and essentially flat compared to prior year of $129 million. Revenue was $139 million, compared to $145 million last year.
Non-GAAP operating income was $159 million, excluding restructuring charges related to Public Safety. non-GAAP operating margin was 31.6% for the quarter and a strong 31.1%  for the full year.
Turning to Government Communications Systems on Slide 8. Fourth quarter revenue was $485 million, up 1% compared to $480 million in the prior year. Higher revenue from the Foundation GEOINT Content Management program, the F-35 program and Highband Networking Radios for the army's WIN-T program was partially offset by lower revenue from 2 classified programs and the Navy's commercial broadband satellite program. Segment operating income was $66 million, and operating margin was 13.7% in the quarter and a strong 15.8% for the full year.
Turning to Integrated Network Solutions on Slide 9. Fourth quarter revenue was $289 million, compared with $373 million in the prior year, a decline of 23%, primarily due to the wind-down of 2 IT Services programs and continued end market weakness for both IT Services and CapRock.
Non-GAAP operating income was $16 million, excluding charges related to restructuring and other items, compared to $33 million in the prior year, primarily due to the wind-down of highly profitable NMCI contract and continued weakness in commercial healthcare.
Moving to fiscal '16 guidance in Slide 10. Today, we're providing high-level guidance on revenue and EPS with some color around fiscal '16 expectations based on the legacy businesses of Harris and Exelis.
Once we have pro forma historical information for fiscal '15 recast into our 4 new segments, we'll provide an outlook by segment as we typically do. We're initiating guidance for GAAP EPS in the range of $5.25 to $5.45, and for non-GAAP, in the range of $5.60 to $5.80.
Fiscal '16 non-GAAP EPS excludes about $60 million to $65 million of integration costs and an $8 million charge related to inventory step-up. It includes about $133 million or about $0.70 per share of Exelis acquisition and tangible amortization.
Fiscal '16 non-GAAP EBIT margin is expected to be in the range of 16.2% to 16.7%. Putting aside for a minute the cost synergies and other impacts related to the acquisition, guidance reflects segment-level operating margin for legacy Exelis slightly lower than the prior year fiscal pro forma of about 12.5%. Harris segment-level operating margin is expected to be about flat with the prior year, based on legacy RF continued strength similar to the prior year, a more normalized operating margin in legacy Government Communications of about 15%, and for IT Services and CapRock together, an operating margin of around 9%.
Other P&L guidance details are outlined on Slide 10. I'll start with an update on expected synergies and integration costs. Our integration team has moved aggressively to capture costs synergies, and is ahead of schedule. As a result, both integration costs and savings are occurring sooner than what we previously expected. We're now on track to achieve fiscal '16 savings of $70 million to $75 million and expect to be at an annual run rate savings of $120 million as we exit fiscal '17, a year sooner than our original estimate and at the top end of our prior range. The $120 million of savings is net of savings that will flow immediately back to the government.
Integration spending was $112 million in fiscal '15, and we expect another $60 million to $65 million in fiscal '16. Total integration costs is now expected to be $150 million, the higher end of our prior range and net of about $25 million of expected reimbursements from the U.S. government, which are not anticipated to begin until fiscal '17. As we move to our greater standardization in processes, policies and operations we'll continue to look for opportunities for further integration savings.
Revenue is expected to be in the range of $7.67 billion to $7.83 billion, down 3% to 5% on a pro forma basis, compared with a fiscal '15 of $8.07 billion. Legacy Harris is expected to be down 2% to 4%. This reflects our initial expectations for Tactical Communications of flat to down slightly, with DoD flat to up low single digits and international flat to down low single digits and continuing weakness in Public Safety with a 2 percentage point decline.
In legacy Government Communications, we expect another growth year of up 2% to 3%. For IT Services and CapRock together, we expect revenue to be down 13% to 15% as a result of continued end market weakness.
Legacy Exelis pro forma stand-alone revenue is expected to be down 5% to 6%, with lower revenue from night vision products and communication products and lower revenue from information systems, primarily from the $85 million roll-off of the Spacelift Range Systems contract that was lost last October.
Slide 11 provides some additional pension information, including an anticipated FAS pension income of about $25 million and ERISA cash contributions of $173 million this fiscal year. With cash funding remaining roughly flat at $170 million in '17 as a result of pension smoothing provided for under the HAFA and MAP-21 legislation. Our unfunded pension liability has declined by about $200 million to $1.9 billion at the end of fiscal '15, principally due to the mandatory funding of the legacy Exelis SERP. The effect of modestly higher discount rates and lower expected return on assets largely offset each other.
So let me please turn it back to Bill for a few wrap-up comments before we open the call for questions.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mick. The revenue outlook that Mick just described anticipates continued budget constraints and the continuing resolution through the end of this calendar year. While the base budget, even under sequestered caps, is bottoming and it's expected
componenttext:
Thank you, Mick. The revenue outlook that Mick just described anticipates continued budget constraints and the continuing resolution through the end of this calendar year. While the base budget, even under sequestered caps, is bottoming and it's expected to slowly improve, the recovery will be gradual with headwinds persisting until budgets improve and drive new program funding. In the meantime, we continue to have a robust growing pipeline of opportunities, which is a positive sign for the future.
We also put in place an outstanding team leading the new organization we recently announced. As you see on Slide 12, we're organized into 4 market-focused segments, and each segment's president is a well-seasoned executive in the government market: Chris Young with 33 years; Carl DAlessandro with 31 years; and Bill Gattle and Ed Zoiss each with 28 years. We've taken our 2 most senior leaders, Sheldon Fox and Dana Mehnert, and focused them on driving greater cost and operational efficiencies and reigniting revenue growth across our company. I also believe we delivered on our promise to put the best of the best from both the Harris and Exelis organizations. This is a tough job in the combined company, with nearly half of the top 50 positions now filled by a former Exelis employee. I think the energy and enthusiasm across the entire company is very high with a lot of excitement about our future.
So as we enter the fiscal year at a running start on integration and focused on exceeding our synergy goals and driving good earnings growth in '16 with even higher accretion in fiscal '17 and fiscal '18.
To conclude, on Slide 13, we're executing very well on all critical integration success factors, from my deep personal ownership of the integration program to the full-time dedicated team led by Sheldon Fox, that's driving a disciplined process with speed and precision, to the close oversight of the board and the constant communication with employees. The result is that we're now at the high end of our prior range of run rate savings achieved about 1 year sooner than previously expected, with 90% of the action underpinning the savings completed or in process in just 70 days since we closed.
I'm really proud of what Harris has accomplished this past year, and I'm optimistic and confident about what our new team of over 23,000 dedicated employees can deliver in the future. Together, we're committed to solving our customers' most complex challenges and driving value for our shareholders.
With that, I'd like to ask the operator to open the lines for questions.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Gautam Khanna from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Gautam Khanna from Cowen and Company.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a couple of questions. First, Bill, I was wondering if you could expand on your earlier comment about looking at things that could be noncore. If you could just talk about what your kind of return metrics are for making that evaluation.
componenttext: I have a couple of questions. First, Bill, I was wondering if you could expand on your earlier comment about looking at things that could be noncore. If you could just talk about what your kind of return metrics are for making that evaluation.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the first thing we're doing is -- I mean, we're looking very hard at what fits strategically or not, and we're also looking at what pieces performed well within our company. And I think you've seen over the last couple of years our willingness to ta
componenttext: Well, the first thing we're doing is -- I mean, we're looking very hard at what fits strategically or not, and we're also looking at what pieces performed well within our company. And I think you've seen over the last couple of years our willingness to take on some tough challenges on businesses that either weren't strategic or core to our company or offered good returns to our shareholders. And I think we've made decisions that add value to our shareowners, and we'll do the same thing going forward. We really don't have any more to date to report, Gautam, but we continue to look at the portfolio, and we'll let shareholders know and you know as we make decisions.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And could you talk a little bit about the pension in Exelis? I know you -- in the slides you mentioned $170 million minimum payment. This year, I mean, are there -- do you have plans underway to kind of minimize that cash payment as move forward? An
componenttext: Okay. And could you talk a little bit about the pension in Exelis? I know you -- in the slides you mentioned $170 million minimum payment. This year, I mean, are there -- do you have plans underway to kind of minimize that cash payment as move forward? Any sort of different approach to the Exelis pension problem that you can talk about?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, certainly we can talk about that. A lot of work has been done on the pension in the past. As you may know, in 2011, the pension was frozen to new hires. In 2011, there was an enhanced defined contribution plan that decreased participants. In '12, had
componenttext: Yes, certainly we can talk about that. A lot of work has been done on the pension in the past. As you may know, in 2011, the pension was frozen to new hires. In 2011, there was an enhanced defined contribution plan that decreased participants. In '12, had a lump-sum program that decreased another amount of participants. And looking forward, we're taking a approach of obligations, not just for pensions, but also for some of the other obligations we have out there. And we're looking at, certainly, derisking the asset portfolio, which is a concern in order to have more traditional investment matching to the liabilities. But looking at the obligations, we have to stratify the pensioneers and future pensioneers and be able to offer lump sums, so we're looking at some of that for the term vested and the traditional approach. So right now, we have a comprehensive study going on. We're using consultants and actuaries to determine what is the best course of action going forward. But we will take an approach towards the pension, both on the asset side and on the liability side, to derisk it and to lower the obligations.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And last one, sales synergies. Can you talk about any opportunities that you're seeing -- that are contemplated in the guidance or not? I don't know. Does it include any sales synergies? Or have you seen...
componenttext: Okay. And last one, sales synergies. Can you talk about any opportunities that you're seeing -- that are contemplated in the guidance or not? I don't know. Does it include any sales synergies? Or have you seen...

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Gautam. Yes. First of all, it does not include any sales synergies. Right now, we're focused on the cost side that we've got out of the gates very, very quickly. As we've talked before, the deal was justified on cost savings, not revenue upside. We c
componenttext: Yes, Gautam. Yes. First of all, it does not include any sales synergies. Right now, we're focused on the cost side that we've got out of the gates very, very quickly. As we've talked before, the deal was justified on cost savings, not revenue upside. We clearly do see revenue opportunities over time. We have a very good team focused on that. We're organized in a way to go and capture some of the revenue upside by the 4 market-focused segments. I think, importantly, we put one of our most seasoned executives that you know well, Dana Mehnert, on top of Global Business Development. One of his responsibilities is to identify and go out and capture some of those revenue opportunity between the companies. So it's something we'll say more about over the course of fiscal '16, maybe not next quarter, but certainly over the course of the year.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Carter Copeland from Barclays. We'll move to the next question. Our next questioner is from -- Seth Seifman from JP Morgan.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Carter Copeland from Barclays. We'll move to the next question. Our next questioner is from -- Seth Seifman from JP Morgan.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, as you look ahead, and I know it's obviously very early to start talking about what might happen beyond next year. But when you think about the overall company and maybe Exelis, specifically, moving to top line growth?
componenttext: I was wondering, as you look ahead, and I know it's obviously very early to start talking about what might happen beyond next year. But when you think about the overall company and maybe Exelis, specifically, moving to top line growth?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, look, we're entering a fiscal '16 where we still have some friction in the system with the government budgets. We do expect a CR to go through the balance of the year. It could extend beyond that. We'll see over the next several months as to what's
componenttext: Well, look, we're entering a fiscal '16 where we still have some friction in the system with the government budgets. We do expect a CR to go through the balance of the year. It could extend beyond that. We'll see over the next several months as to what's happening in D.C., and that does some put some challenges in our business and certainly with Exelis as well. But we do see, even under sequestered budgets, budgets improving in fiscal '17, fiscal '18. I'm very, very encouraged, Seth, that we are seeing some of the modernization spending on tactical radios start to move. And I feel good about where we're at on Rifleman. I'm really glad to see the Manpack RFP come out a couple of days ago. I'm glad to see that they're moving quickly with a 60-day proposal time period and expecting to make awards in December if all things go smoothly in negotiations. So these, I think, are good signs that there's money moving or will move over time, and I do feel pretty optimistic that will allow our company to grow, maybe not next year, but certainly in years beyond that, Seth.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just as a quick follow-up on the international radio. And can you talk about maybe being flat to slightly down next year? If you could just talk about anything shifting in terms of the regional dynamics, and I know you mentioned your Austra
componenttext: And then maybe just as a quick follow-up on the international radio. And can you talk about maybe being flat to slightly down next year? If you could just talk about anything shifting in terms of the regional dynamics, and I know you mentioned your Australia opportunity that comes kind of beyond the pipeline portfolio, but anything that's kind of shifting in the portfolio and the pipeline? And what -- if there's any kind of trajectory to the outlook beyond this year for international radio.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, the international business process, as you know, has been very, very strong. And we ended the year and Q4 very strong. The orders were extraordinary. I'm very glad to see the revenue was up for the full year. It was at the high end of what w
componenttext: Sure. I mean, the international business process, as you know, has been very, very strong. And we ended the year and Q4 very strong. The orders were extraordinary. I'm very glad to see the revenue was up for the full year. It was at the high end of what we were guiding to, nearly 10%, so we feel very good about where we ended the year. The pipeline is still pretty robust at about $2.4 billion, last quarter it's $2.5 billion. I wouldn't read a light into that, it moves around a little bit time to time, but it's still very solid at $2.4 billion. The shape of the pipeline looks pretty much like it has over the last couple of quarters. More than half of it is into the Middle East, Northern Africa, Central Asia. And that does seem, still, to be pretty robust, but we do see in the Middle East, in 2 specific countries, some stretching out of some opportunities, which we believe, over time, are very big for the company. One is in Iraq, and the other is in Saudi Arabia and Iraq. Certainly, the price of oil that's with WTI should be just a little bit below $45 a barrel, that's causing some impact on direct commercial sales. We do know that Iraq sales for us are boxed up by the U.S. government foreign military funding. But there are some new commanders in Iraq, and that's taking a bit slower for some of those sales into Iraq to take place. So Iraq is slipping a little bit. And in Saudi, oil is causing a little bit of a problem there. There's a new leadership team in Saudi Arabia. And certainly, the strife in Yemen is causing some shifting around the priorities. Those are the 2 things that have shifted a little bit further to the right. We do see multiyear opportunities in the hundreds of millions of dollars in both Iraq and Saudi Arabia, so we feel good about those. Australia is very strong for us. I mentioned in my remarks a $750 million Phase 3 opportunity, that's outside of our pipeline, but it's real. We're participating in that, and that's going to end up happening. So longer term, we do see good opportunities in international. You'll recall, at the beginning of fiscal '15, we started international tactical with relatively modest guidance of up low single digits, and we ended up at about 10%. And I hope, going into fiscal '16, we're being similarly conservative.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Pete Skibitski from Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Pete Skibitski from Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, I guess, just on the prior target of $1 billion in free cash by year 4, can you update us? Are you sticking with that? And what year should we think of as year 4 at this point?
componenttext: Bill, I guess, just on the prior target of $1 billion in free cash by year 4, can you update us? Are you sticking with that? And what year should we think of as year 4 at this point?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, year 4, probably will go out from 4 years when I first made the comment, so I wouldn't want to accelerate that from here. But I still feel confident on the $1 billion of free cash flow. When I look at just where we happen to be, guiding this year at
componenttext: Well, year 4, probably will go out from 4 years when I first made the comment, so I wouldn't want to accelerate that from here. But I still feel confident on the $1 billion of free cash flow. When I look at just where we happen to be, guiding this year at more than 100% of adjusted GAAP net income, excluding amortization, the after-tax amortization, when you're on the map on that, it's sort of in the $750 million range with a lot of moving parts, and we're just getting started. You add on top of that, run rate savings, some improvements on working capital, some more tightening down on capital spending and other things. And I do see that, over the next 3, 4 years, we could definitely get to $1 billion of free cash, so no, I'm not backing off that target.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on capital deployment. It looks like you kind of turned off the repurchase program, at least for this year. Is that right? And then maybe what's the right level of debt paydown to factor in this year?
componenttext: Okay. And then just on capital deployment. It looks like you kind of turned off the repurchase program, at least for this year. Is that right? And then maybe what's the right level of debt paydown to factor in this year?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's as we had signaled before, our #1 priority outside of funding our own internal requirements was of course is embedded in free cash flow and making sure that we continue to pay an attractive dividend. Beyond that, our #1 priority is debt paydow
componenttext: Yes, that's as we had signaled before, our #1 priority outside of funding our own internal requirements was of course is embedded in free cash flow and making sure that we continue to pay an attractive dividend. Beyond that, our #1 priority is debt paydown, and that's what we're going to do, and that's -- it's important for us to delever. We still have the targets out there, going from 2.9x net leverage to 1.5 over the next 3 years, and that's our #1 priority. So for the course of fiscal '16, in our current guidance, we've assumed no share buyback.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And then just last one, maybe more for Mick. But the deal amortization of $133 million, is that kind of the same level in '17 and '18 or does that run off pretty quickly? And can you help us with kind of how it loads across the quarter for '
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then just last one, maybe more for Mick. But the deal amortization of $133 million, is that kind of the same level in '17 and '18 or does that run off pretty quickly? And can you help us with kind of how it loads across the quarter for '16?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Of the $1.6 billion, about $1.4 billion is in customer relations. The rest is in technology, trademarks, brands and so forth. But there's a little bit which is for the Exelis brand, and that gets amortized over 2 years. So we expect to have $13
componenttext: Yes, sure. Of the $1.6 billion, about $1.4 billion is in customer relations. The rest is in technology, trademarks, brands and so forth. But there's a little bit which is for the Exelis brand, and that gets amortized over 2 years. So we expect to have $133 million for the next 2 years, and then it's $125 million or a little bit less in the others.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Josh Sullivan from Sterne CRT.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Josh Sullivan from Sterne CRT.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: What kind of impact does a 0.25-point raise in interest rates have on the pension obligation?
componenttext: What kind of impact does a 0.25-point raise in interest rates have on the pension obligation?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the sensitivity for a 0.25 point is -- and there's complexity here, right, so 25 basis points up is a decrease of $171 million. And 25 basis points down is an increase of $208.5 million on our liability. On the income, 25 basis points, it's about
componenttext: Yes. So the sensitivity for a 0.25 point is -- and there's complexity here, right, so 25 basis points up is a decrease of $171 million. And 25 basis points down is an increase of $208.5 million on our liability. On the income, 25 basis points, it's about $8 million. Does that answer your question?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then just on the Healthcare divestiture. How much was it losing here? And then did you receive any compensation for the transaction?
componenttext: Yes. And then just on the Healthcare divestiture. How much was it losing here? And then did you receive any compensation for the transaction?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: We did. You'll see in the table that we're presenting, and you'll see it in our K that we received about $43 million net cash-in, in the fourth quarter for the sale of Healthcare. The transaction was about $50 million is something that's sitting in escrow
componenttext: We did. You'll see in the table that we're presenting, and you'll see it in our K that we received about $43 million net cash-in, in the fourth quarter for the sale of Healthcare. The transaction was about $50 million is something that's sitting in escrow, the cash-in was about $43 million. It gave us a pretax gain in the quarter of about $8 million. So when you look at a year-over-year basis, it's worth about $12 million delta between fiscal '15 and '16 in terms of the Healthcare impact.

componenttext: We've got a lot of work to do here on just restating the historicals. And I would say that, I'm looking to Mick, but I think we'll be able to provide outlook guidance in segment historicals restated certainly in our Q1 release. We can't commit today that it will be any sooner than that, but it will be, at the latest, at our Q1 release.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
