componenttext: Yes, there's a piece of it, about $19 million that's just, as Mick had mentioned, is the write-down of an intangible associated with the NMCI contract that went away over the course of fiscal '15, and that's about half of it. The balance is restructuring at CapRock.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. And then lastly, just, Bill, some of the other big opportunities, the SOCOM STC and I think the Air Force had a big program, and there's SANR. Anything kind of looking like it's in the 12-month pipeline in terms of a potential award there?
componenttext: Okay. Okay. And then lastly, just, Bill, some of the other big opportunities, the SOCOM STC and I think the Air Force had a big program, and there's SANR. Anything kind of looking like it's in the 12-month pipeline in terms of a potential award there?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Nothing in the 12-month pipeline. STC, we have a baffle win and the award is expected in September, if they move on the path that they say they're going to move on. And that's on the 2-channel handheld. There's a bigger program going forward in the Manpac
componenttext: Nothing in the 12-month pipeline. STC, we have a baffle win and the award is expected in September, if they move on the path that they say they're going to move on. And that's on the 2-channel handheld. There's a bigger program going forward in the Manpack and in HF radio that you will see RFPs on later in September, but that's the current trajectory on STC. And in SANR and SALT, they're going to make some decisions on these programs over the coming months, we believe. It really depends upon what happens in the fiscal '16 budget, but we currently are shipping our STT radios for what is considered as SALT, the Small Airborne Link 16 Terminal program, and we're already shipping our STT product in concert with ViaSat. And on SANR it's hard to say whether it's going to go. That's a WNW or SRW 2-channel radio for a bunch of military rotary aircraft programs, but I think they wouldn't expect any production awards on that to something like GFY '19. So it's pretty far out there in the future, and it's not in our horizon.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: We do have a follow-up from Gautam Khanna from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: We do have a follow-up from Gautam Khanna from Cowen and Company.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, can you comment a little about how you're going to preserve profitability at the RF Tactical business unit, given you have some LPTA-type bids coming up. So if you were to win Manpack, for example, presumably, pricing will be under some pressure. An
componenttext: Bill, can you comment a little about how you're going to preserve profitability at the RF Tactical business unit, given you have some LPTA-type bids coming up. So if you were to win Manpack, for example, presumably, pricing will be under some pressure. And I just wondered if you could talk about some of the levers you have, be it R&D, year-to-year, what are your expectations and other factors?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, I think the team has done a really outstanding job, not just in the last 3 years or the last decade in taking costs out of the product. And I've given some examples on prior calls on what the team has done in the 117G to take costs out
componenttext: Well, first of all, I think the team has done a really outstanding job, not just in the last 3 years or the last decade in taking costs out of the product. And I've given some examples on prior calls on what the team has done in the 117G to take costs out every year, post its launch. And I would see that we'll be able to do the same thing as these new products start to come into the portfolio and mature. At the end of the day, we've got probably the largest tactical radio facility in the world. It's going to become even more utilized as we bring in the tactical radio business from Ft. Wayne. It's both the international and the DoD business running in the same facility. It's a 0.5 million square feet of world-class manufacturing. Huge supply chain leverage. And on top of that, we're spending, give or take, $100 million a year on tactical radio innovations, which I do believe will continue to put features into our products, over time, which will allow us to continue to drive, we hope, to be premium prices versus our competitors. I think all of those things will allow us to maintain our margins in Tactical, and that's what we certainly expect at Harris.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And can you help size the MNVR opportunity? Where that's been running at and where do you think it's going to go on an annual run rate basis?
componenttext: And can you help size the MNVR opportunity? Where that's been running at and where do you think it's going to go on an annual run rate basis?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's been in about $10 million or $15 million over the last year or 2. I think we book between $15 million, $20 million worth of orders or thereabout. We expect in fiscal '16, Gautam, about $20 million worth of revenue, and then it will ramp a little bit
componenttext: It's been in about $10 million or $15 million over the last year or 2. I think we book between $15 million, $20 million worth of orders or thereabout. We expect in fiscal '16, Gautam, about $20 million worth of revenue, and then it will ramp a little bit beyond that, probably up maybe 2x or 3x beyond into fiscal '17. Again, it depends on what happens as to when they issue the full-rate production award, how they want to field it because that's changing a little bit in some of the BCP changes that are happening in the Army. As that settles down, we do know that '17 is going to ramp from '16, and we think '16 is around $20 million of revenue, more or less.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one last one, if you could just also help size HMS Manpack should you win it. I just wonder, you do sell some 117Gs now. And if you could just talk about cannibalization, if there is any, if you were to prevail on Manpack. [indiscernible]
componenttext: Okay. And one last one, if you could just also help size HMS Manpack should you win it. I just wonder, you do sell some 117Gs now. And if you could just talk about cannibalization, if there is any, if you were to prevail on Manpack. [indiscernible]

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: First of all, yes -- Gautam, sorry to interrupt you. On the Manpack, it's not going to affect our revenue until our fiscal '18, that's what we're thinking at the moment, based on the schedule, as we see it. If you look at just between Rifleman and the Man
componenttext: First of all, yes -- Gautam, sorry to interrupt you. On the Manpack, it's not going to affect our revenue until our fiscal '18, that's what we're thinking at the moment, based on the schedule, as we see it. If you look at just between Rifleman and the Manpack, the PBR is about $0.5 billion per year for that HMS program. And over a decade, that's $5 billion between Rifleman and Manpack, and that's our best guess on a decade-wide opportunity. Obviously, our revenue is going to depend on our share of both Rifleman and the Manpack, but it will affect our fiscal '18 revenue on the Manpack, probably fiscal '17 for the Rifleman. In terms of cannibalization, we've given a lot of thinking to this, and we believe that it will be mostly incremental to our base business today. Because it's being bought -- the modernization is being bought by different parts of the service than what are buying replacement Gs, spares and other things. So our sense is that it will be mostly incremental, with not so much cannibalization, Gautam.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Chris Quilty from Raymond James.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Chris Quilty from Raymond James.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I haven't yet made it through the whole 689-page Manpack solicitation, but can you comment on any puts and takes you see in the document relative to your design and competitiveness? And can you comment specifically on the proposal for the light version an
componenttext: I haven't yet made it through the whole 689-page Manpack solicitation, but can you comment on any puts and takes you see in the document relative to your design and competitiveness? And can you comment specifically on the proposal for the light version and how well you are positioned for that?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I didn't get through 689 pages, Chris, either. But we had a really, really good Tactical [ph] that summarized it brilliantly in 4 or 5 pages. And I think -- look, nothing -- not much has changed from the very good dialogue interaction we had with the
componenttext: Yes. I didn't get through 689 pages, Chris, either. But we had a really, really good Tactical [ph] that summarized it brilliantly in 4 or 5 pages. And I think -- look, nothing -- not much has changed from the very good dialogue interaction we had with the Army during the draft RFP process. It was a couple of industry days. I mean, as you know, that's been percolating for quite some time. There's been a lot of active dialogue, a lot conversation on range, power, weight. Was it radio weight, mission weight? Is MUOS in? Is it out? There's been a lot of puts and takes. At the end of the day, the final RFP is in line with what we had expected. What I think is very interesting is that what they're going to do is look for, at the time of award, you have to meet certain threshold requirements, and one of which is a 16-pound mission weight. They're going to give you some additional, if you will, leverage for MUOS and some antennas and other things. Then they have a deferred threshold set of requirements that have to be met by June of 2017. And then a series of objective requirements that will fold in, over time, based on how industry evolves to capture some of these opportunities. Again like around power, weight, et cetera. So that's the way we see it shaking out. This whole light Manpack opportunity is going to be kind of interesting, and I don't know where it's ultimately going to go. They're looking for a lower-weight Manpack, maybe feature some of the Manpack. It could potentially, Chris, be something like a 2-channel handheld that would go to a SOCOM and maybe, over time, go into the regular Army. So it's -- we're unclear as to how that's going to evolve over time. But that's essentially the way we see 689 pages in a nutshell.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And with regard to the 13% to 15% decline in IT Services and CapRock. Can you break it out between the 2 businesses and comment specifically around where you see the CapRock, the energy business trending relative to where you thought it would be 6 months
componenttext: And with regard to the 13% to 15% decline in IT Services and CapRock. Can you break it out between the 2 businesses and comment specifically around where you see the CapRock, the energy business trending relative to where you thought it would be 6 months ago?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes. The -- on IT Services, we see down about 15%. We see CapRock, as a whole, down about 10%. And in the CapRock down about 10%, we're seeing the energy business down about 20%. And maybe just to give you a little color on this, back in Q2 and Q3,
componenttext: Sure. Yes. The -- on IT Services, we see down about 15%. We see CapRock, as a whole, down about 10%. And in the CapRock down about 10%, we're seeing the energy business down about 20%. And maybe just to give you a little color on this, back in Q2 and Q3, the orders were quite good. We did expect the second half revenue in CapRock to turn down, it in fact did. We came in spot-on what we thought we would be in terms of the CapRock revenue for the year. We were down in Q4 about 13%. Of course, we're seeing now price of oil just below $45. There's a potential deal with -- there's a rand [ph] issue that could drop price of oil down even further. We've calibrated going forward, for CapRock Energy, into fiscal '16 down about 20%. We did see in the last quarter a lot of the oil majors, oil service companies have done more restructuring. Rig count is down globally around 36%. We think we've calibrated for current events in CapRock being down about 20% next year. But again, we're watching very, very carefully what is happening to the price of oil, but more importantly, the behavior of our major customers in response to the price of oil, and we're just simply reacting to what they're doing.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Noah Poponak from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Noah Poponak from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, so I guess, what are the prospects for eventually moving above the $120 million synergy run rate? It's obviously quite impressive that you were able to move it forward a full year in such a short period of time. But I guess, how much of it -- how mu
componenttext: Bill, so I guess, what are the prospects for eventually moving above the $120 million synergy run rate? It's obviously quite impressive that you were able to move it forward a full year in such a short period of time. But I guess, how much of it -- how much is this -- you had identified everything and have just been able to do it much faster versus finding new things or  there being potential to find a lot more opportunity to go even higher than 1 point?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, Noah, our diligence was very, very good. And we're finding that most of the opportunities that we thought we would capture, we have captured, and not much has changed. We knew, right out of the gate, the first thing we would attack wou
componenttext: Well, first of all, Noah, our diligence was very, very good. And we're finding that most of the opportunities that we thought we would capture, we have captured, and not much has changed. We knew, right out of the gate, the first thing we would attack would be the public company cost, and we did that right out of the gate. And we knew there was an opportunity on the tactical radio side between the 2 facilities that we had, and we went at that very, very quickly. So most of the things that we had anticipated, we're executing on. As I said, about 90% of the actions that we've contemplated going after $120 million are completed or in process. So we feel pretty good about that. So look, as I said, we're 70 days in, and we're at the high end of the range we gave before. As we go forward, we continue to find new opportunities. Will there be some things that work against us? Sure. Without a doubt. But I do believe that we have a good opportunity to continue to drive it above $120 million today. Our best guess for where we stand today is $120 million.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the cost to achieve synergy that I believe was previously outlined as $130 million to $150 million, has that moved -- I'm not 100% sure that I'm squaring that up with Slide 10.
componenttext: Okay. And the cost to achieve synergy that I believe was previously outlined as $130 million to $150 million, has that moved -- I'm not 100% sure that I'm squaring that up with Slide 10.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me give you some color on that because, first off, the $120 million on the savings, as Mick have mentioned, we reimbursed the government directly in the year immediately on the $120 million. On the cost to achieve, it was $130 million to $150 million.
componenttext: Let me give you some color on that because, first off, the $120 million on the savings, as Mick have mentioned, we reimbursed the government directly in the year immediately on the $120 million. On the cost to achieve, it was $130 million to $150 million. That was net of expected government reimbursements, and that was going to happen over a 2- to 3-year time period. We had $112 million worth of integration and project costs hit us at fiscal '15. We have another $60 million to $65 million hit in fiscal '16. You put them together, it's about $175 million. We do expect about $25 million reimbursement by the government sometime in fiscal '17 or beyond, and that's what gets us to the $150 million.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I see. Okay, that's helpful. And then just a follow-up on that CapRock question. I mean, down 20% is not insignificant, but you mentioned what rig count has done and it's more. And you mentioned what the actual fuel price has done and it's more. What is i
componenttext: I see. Okay, that's helpful. And then just a follow-up on that CapRock question. I mean, down 20% is not insignificant, but you mentioned what rig count has done and it's more. And you mentioned what the actual fuel price has done and it's more. What is it about CapRock that would make it outperform the broader industry?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's really the mix of the rigs. When we say rig count is down 36%, that's land, that's near offshore, it's deep offshore, ultra-deep. And we're -- because the assets, the value of deep offshore rigs are so great for the oil companies, they tend to
componenttext: Well, it's really the mix of the rigs. When we say rig count is down 36%, that's land, that's near offshore, it's deep offshore, ultra-deep. And we're -- because the assets, the value of deep offshore rigs are so great for the oil companies, they tend to stay in production longer. We're more disposed to offshore and deep offshore. That's where the revenue happens to be. So even though rig count is coming down, like on land, quite a bit more than 36%, not a lot of revenue for CapRock going into the land side, a lot more on the offshore and deep offshore.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I see. And then anything -- any color or comments you could provide on what potential you see in the Exelis -- the legacy Exelis business base margin beyond this year? Should we think of that as pretty flattish over time? Or is there opportunity for that
componenttext: I see. And then anything -- any color or comments you could provide on what potential you see in the Exelis -- the legacy Exelis business base margin beyond this year? Should we think of that as pretty flattish over time? Or is there opportunity for that to change? Or does it have headwinds going forward?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's coming down slightly in fiscal '16 from '15, and that's partly due to revenue coming down a little bit. We're guiding it down 5% to 6%. When we go back to old segments of Exelis, we do see the Electronic Systems and the Night Vision Comms busin
componenttext: Well, it's coming down slightly in fiscal '16 from '15, and that's partly due to revenue coming down a little bit. We're guiding it down 5% to 6%. When we go back to old segments of Exelis, we do see the Electronic Systems and the Night Vision Comms business both being down in fiscal '15 about mid-single-digits. The IS business, Information Systems, would be down about 10%, with the largest piece of that, 7 or 8 points roughly, that's from the loss of a contract, this range support contract, that was lost in October of last year. And we do see the Arrow business up mid-teens, that's growing pretty nicely with content with Boeing with Airbus, with the F-35 ramp, the 53k with Sikorsky. They got some good programs there. So when I look at all the pieces and how they're moving around and what's growing, the Arrow business does have lower margin, so when that grows faster than the others, it does depress the overall margin rate a little bit. But I do see that there is some softening in the margins for Night Vision Comms. And I do see some softening in the Electronic Systems business as they transition from what were production programs to some more development programs, and that's sort of a natural transition. So they were down I think right about 12.5% pro forma last year, if I remember right, and we're guiding to be slightly less than that in fiscal '16.

I don't think I'll go out any further than '16, as I wouldn't do for the core business either for Harris. But that is basically where we stand on the revenue outlook for Exelis, I think you have the backlog here, Mick, handy.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Harris Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference may be recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Pamela Padgett, Vi
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Harris Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference may be recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Pamela Padgett, Vice President of Investor Relations. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Hi, good morning, everyone. Welcome to the first quarter fiscal 2016 earnings call. I'm Pamela Padgett. And on the call today is Bill Brown, Chairman and CEO; Mick Lopez, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Sheldon Fox, Senior Vice President and
componenttext:
Thank you. Hi, good morning, everyone. Welcome to the first quarter fiscal 2016 earnings call. I'm Pamela Padgett. And on the call today is Bill Brown, Chairman and CEO; Mick Lopez, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Sheldon Fox, Senior Vice President and Integration Lead. 
Before we get started, a few words on forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements made today involve assumptions, risk and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those statements. For more information and discussion of such assumptions, risks and uncertainties, please see the press release, the presentations Harris SEC filings. In addition, a reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures discussed today to comparable GAAP measures is included on the Investor Relations section of our website, which is www.harris.com and where replay of this call will be available. 
And with that, Bill, I'll turn it over to you.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, thank you, Pam, and good morning everybody. Our first quarter was a solid start to the fiscal year and was our first full quarter including Exelis' operations. Integration of Exelis is progressing well, with cost savings dropping through the r
componenttext:
Okay. Well, thank you, Pam, and good morning everybody. Our first quarter was a solid start to the fiscal year and was our first full quarter including Exelis' operations. Integration of Exelis is progressing well, with cost savings dropping through the results in Q1 and expected to ramp quickly through the balance of the year. 
Coming out of the gates, I was very pleased with first quarter orders strength, particularly for tactical radios, electronic warfare and intelligent systems, which resulted in a book-to-bill of 1.24 for the company and 6% sequential growth in funded backlog. And we're delivering on our commitment to delever, paying down term debt by $150 million in the quarter while continuing to pay an attractive dividend, which was increased in August for the 14th consecutive year. 
Harris is now operating in 4 new business segments: Communication Systems, Space and Intelligent Systems, Electronic Systems and Critical Networks. In a separate filing yesterday, we provided historical pro forma information for fiscal '14 and '15, combining Harris' and Exelis' historical results as if the companies had previously operated together under the new segment structure, information we believe is helpful for understanding year-over-year trends. We'll refer to these comparisons as organic in today's call and presentation materials. I'll also remind you that all of our comments address non-GAAP results excluding acquisition-related costs. 
So turning to Slide 3, 4 and 5 in the presentation. Revenue in Q1 was $1.81 billion compared to $1.16 billion in the prior year and was higher because of the acquisition. On an organic basis, revenue was down 6%, driven in large part by continuing weakness in the government and energy services markets. Earnings per share was $1.31 and included $0.17 of intangible amortization from the Exelis acquisition. Acquisition-related savings are reading through an improving operating income with EBIT before amortization of intangibles up 7% to $319 million and margin increasing more than 200 basis points to 17.6%. Cost synergies were $11 million in the quarter and were on track to reach our fiscal year targets of $70 million to $75 million. 
Also captured in improving operating performance is our ongoing focus on what we call Harris Business Excellence, our operational excellence program which targets 2% to 3% annual net cost reduction. In addition to supporting margins, our strategy is to reinvest some of these savings into R&D and new product development to drive future growth. And in Q1, we continued to spend at a healthy rate of 4.3% of revenue. Q1 orders were $2.24 billion with book-to-bill of 1.24 and with all 4 segments greater than 1. In Harris' legacy tactical radio business, orders increased 30% and book-to-bill was 1.3  with strength in both U.S. DoD and international markets.  Our international tactical radio business continues to be supported by a pipeline of near- and longer-term opportunities across a broad set of geographies and driven by ongoing global security concerns from NATO responding to Russian aggression to conflict across the Middle East, Central Asia and Africa. In Northern Africa, the U.S. is gearing up to combat rising terrorism. And the tilt to the Pacific is providing significant multiyear opportunities in Australia. And U.S. funding support for foreign military sales remain strong, both in the base budget as well as in the OCO accounts. OCO funding in FY '15 and proposed in FY '16 is supporting several special initiatives like the European reassurance initiative to counterterrorism partnership fund that supports regional -- regions of instability in the Middle East and Africa and to train and equip fund for Iraq. 
First quarter tactical orders were underpinned by the strong U.S. funding support and included $38 million and $26 million from a country in Central Asia, $39 million from 2 Baltic countries and $27 million from several countries in the Middle East and Africa. Also progressing through procurement are opportunities supported by the Iraq train and equip fund with the first of these opportunities in the low 10s of millions and expected to book in Q2. 
In the U.S. market, our base business continue to be supported by recent opportunities in sustainment, which was reflected in 1Q's broad-based orders strength across the services and included a $100 million single-sourced IDIQ ceiling increase to $500 million for tactical radio spare part purchases by the Army and other agencies. 
A very big strategic win in the quarter, which is currently under protest, is the $390 million SOCOM 2-channel handheld tactical radio. This radio combines communication and ISR capabilities and can receive full-motion video as well as signals-based threat information. SOCOM is typically an early adopter of technology, so we're encouraged that continuing to invest our own company-funded R&D is a winning strategy supporting our already strong competitive position. 
Similar to other products first developed for the U.S. market, we fully expect this new 2-channel handheld will generate strong international demand. This win is part of a larger monetization program that SOCOM has estimated could reach $900 million and include a multichannel Manpack radio expected to be awarded in the fall of 2016 and high-frequency radio expected to be awarded in the summer of 2017. In 
addition to the SOCOM award, we're seeing other signs of momentum building for broad-based U.S. tactical modernization. In early October, we submitted our bid for the Army's 2-channel Manpack radio with award anticipated early next calendar year, and our MNVR mid-tier radio for the Army is slated for a milestone C-decision in the coming months. In the airborne market, we've been selling Link 16 radios codeveloped with Viasat to upgrade a Apache aircraft. And with the program now canceled, we'll continue to be the sole provider for that mission. 
The more significant airborne opportunity in the horizon is the Small Airborne Networking Radio, or SANR, program valued at $700 million, which has been pushed out -- which had been pushed out by budgetary pressures. Funding for SANR has begun, and the first draft RFP is out with the second expected in December. First production buys are currently expected to begin in GFY 19. 
We also had excellent wins from classified customers receiving orders of $184 million, up significantly over the prior year and primarily in support of advance center systems and space superiority. With a pivot to Asia, space superiority and protection has become a U.S. defense priority, and recent reports suggest spending in this area could reach $8 billion over the next 5 years. We also saw nice recovery in electronic warfare orders, including slips from the prior quarter with the wins coming from across the air, ground and maritime domains of our EW franchise. In the air domain, we received orders of $111 million from the Air Force primarily for the B-52 and $97 million from the Navy for the F-18. And we won a 5-year, $78 million single award IDIQ from a DoD customer for rotary aircraft. In the ground domain, EW orders included $27 million for the U.S. Department of State for EGON counter IED systems. And supporting the maritime domain, we awarded 3 contracts, a $113 million contract with an initial $39 million order from the U.S. Naval Sea Systems Command for radar modification kits, a 2-year $49  million production contract for launchers used to conduct underwater acoustic surveillance on 25 U.S. and 8 Australian P8 Poseidon aircraft and a 3-year $54 million single-award IDIQ from the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory for the Advanced Decoy Architecture Payloads program ADAP. the ADAP award is a strategic win. It allows us to enter a new market with the potential to grow longer term. Our solutions provide capabilities to address advanced maritime threats beyond what current decoys provide. And because our solutions allow us the customer to retrofit existing decoy shelves with our payload, it's cost-effective and it's quick. 
As you know, Sheldon Fox is leading our integration efforts. And as we promised investors in the board, Sheldon and his team are dedicated full time to successfully integrating de 2 companies. So before Mick provides detailed results and guidance on the new segment basis, I've asked Sheldon to join us today to provide a status update and highlight one of our larger integration projects. Sheldon?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. Our integration begin with a running start at closing, and within the first 70 days, we had 90% of the actions underpinning the savings completed or in process. And we'll continue along aggressive path to quick
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. Our integration begin with a running start at closing, and within the first 70 days, we had 90% of the actions underpinning the savings completed or in process. And we'll continue along aggressive path to quickly execute against our plan and expect to generate between $70 million and $75 million in savings in fiscal '16, well on our way to achieving the $120 million run rate savings as we exit fiscal '17. We're executing fast and executing with a great deal of focus. Each cost synergy project has a dedicated team and a detailed plan which is tracked weekly. 
Bill asked me to provide a little color on the key project with highlights the value we're creating through integration. In July, we announced the closure of Exelis' Ft. Wayne tactical radio facility and consolidation into our world-class Rochester manufacturing facility. In the first quarter, the last radio rolled off a line in Ft. Wayne, and all manufacturing operations will wrap up by fiscal year-end. Currently, we're taking steps to ensure that engineering and manufacturing know-how is fully transferred to Rochester, including moving key employees. 
Slide 6 shows the fourth base in Rochester designated and prepped for the transition. The reduction in manufacturing square footage for production is significant, reducing the footprint from 90,000 square feet to 20,000 square feet and reducing 6 SMT lines down to 2. The entire facility in Fort Wayne is about 300,000 square feet. Once SINCGARS is transitioned, we'll shrink the remaining space being utilized to about 30,000 square feet until the lease expires in December of 2017. Our actions will begin to produce savings in the fourth quarter of fiscal '16 with additional savings to fall to optimizing our supply base and leveraging the scale and efficiency of the Rochester facility. But why is all this important? Because SINCGARS remains an important communications capability around the world. The SINCGARS radio line has an install base of 600,000 radios worldwide, with about 550,000 of those in the U.S. In the domestic market, there's a very long tail of replacement and sustainment. So executing a seamless manufacturing transition will be important in supporting and eventually transitioning SINCGARSs' users to new JTRS radios. And in international market, demand for SINCGARS radios is still fairly strong. While one of the larger initial projects, Ft. Wayne is just one of the many projects in progress. Integration process will be a multiyear effort, and we're still in the early innings. We're off to a terrific start. 
I'll turn it over to Mick.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sheldon. Glad to have you on the call. Good morning to everyone. Slide 7, we provide descriptions within the segments. The following segment slides show prior year pro forma results as Exelis and Harris were combined for all of 2015. We believe
componenttext:
Thank you, Sheldon. Glad to have you on the call. Good morning to everyone. Slide 7, we provide descriptions within the segments. The following segment slides show prior year pro forma results as Exelis and Harris were combined for all of 2015. We believe this results into more meaningful year-over-year organic comparisons. 
Moving to segment results starting on Slide 8. Communication system segment revenue was $454 million compared to prior year pro forma revenue of $469 million, and increase in Tactical Communications was more than offset by weakness in Public Safety where competitive pressures remain challenging. Within de segment, Tactical Communications has been redefined as a combination of both companies ground and airborne tactical radios with Exelis night vision products. We provided that detail on Slide 8. On this new basis, Tactical Communications revenue is up 1%, primarily driven by a 7% increase in Harris' legacy tactical, partially offset by lower expected revenue in Exelis' legacy tactical and night vision product lines. 
In Public Safety, revenue was $92 million compared to $111 million in the prior year. Communication system segment operating performance improved compared to prior year pro forma. Operating income in the first quarter was $138 million, and operating margin was 30.4% compared to last year's operating income of $125 million and 26.7% margin. 
Turning to space and intelligent systems on Slide 9. First quarter revenue was $435 million compared to prior year pro forma revenue of $455 million. Higher revenue from 2 programs, including the Foundation GEOINT Content Management program, was more than offset by the completion of 2 other classified programs and a commercial space payable program. Segment operating performance improved compared to prior year pro forma. Operating income in the first quarter was $68 million, and operating margin was 15.6% compared to last year's operating income of $57 million and 12.5% margin. 
Turning to Electronic Systems on Slide 10. First quarter revenue was $374 million compared to $378 million in the prior year. Higher revenue from the F-35 production ramp was offset by lower electronic warfare revenue. This was primarily due to a higher mix of programs in the development phase versus production phases. Segment operating performance improved compared to prior year pro forma. Operating income in the first quarter was $69 million, and operating margin was 18.4% compared to last year's operating income of $56 million and 14.8% margin. 
Turning to Critical Networks on Slide 11. First quarter revenue was $566 million compared to prior year pro forma revenue of $644 million. As anticipated, revenue declined due to continuing services weakness in government and energy markets. Segment operating income was $63 million compared to prior year pro forma of $72 million, and operating margin held relatively in line with the prior year on lower revenue. 
Moving to Slide 12 and 13. Fiscal '16 guidance remains unchanged for GAAP EPS in a range of $5.25 to $5.45 and non-GAAP in a range of $5.60 to $5.80. Fiscal '16 non-GAAP EPS excludes expected integration cost in a range of $60 million to $65 million and $10 million charge related to inventory step-up. Non-GAAP EPS includes the intangible amortization from the Exelis acquisition of $133 million or about $0.70 per share. Revenue guidance is unchanged in a range of $7.67 billion to $7.83 billion, down 3% to 5% on an organic basis compared to fiscal '15 pro forma of $8.09 billion kept. And whilst segments have changed, our expectations for revenue drivers within the segments are consistent with the previous color we provide. In communication systems, we expect organic revenue to be down 2% to 3%. Public Safety is expected to be down low to mid-single digits. Tactical Communications on the new basis, including the ground and airborne radio for both companies as well as night vision products, is expected to be down low single digits. This aligns with our previous expectations for Harris legacy tactical; DoD flat to up low single digits; and international, flat to down low single digits. Operating margin for the segment is expected to be in the range of 29.5% to 30.5%, which assumes legacy Harris tactical margin in line with fiscal '15 and consistent with previous expectations. 
In space and intelligent systems, revenue is expected to be flat to up 2% with growth in intelligence areas, partially offset by lower revenue from space payload programs. Segment operating margin is expected to be in the range of 15.5% to 16.5%. Electronic Systems revenue is expected to be down 1% to up 1%, driven by the F-35 production ramp. Segment operating margin is expected to be in a range of 18% to 19%. 
In Critical Networks, revenue is expected to be down 10% to 12% due to continuing services weaknesses, with an operating margin in a range of 11% to 12% as we keep the focus on lowering costs. We continue to expect free cash flow for the year greater than 100% of GAAP net income adjusted to add back the $88 million after-tax impact of the amortization of acquisition intangibles. 
So let me turn it over to Bill for a few wrap-up comments before we open the call to questions.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks, Mick. So I won't repeat the budget detail that all of you already know, but suffice it to say the 2-year deal will be a positive for Harris as well as the industry, signaling a long-awaited budget bottom and the rise in government spending.
componenttext:
Okay, thanks, Mick. So I won't repeat the budget detail that all of you already know, but suffice it to say the 2-year deal will be a positive for Harris as well as the industry, signaling a long-awaited budget bottom and the rise in government spending. Overall, we had a good start to the fiscal year. We're capturing integration savings, which will continue to ramp through the year and benefit earnings. And while we continue to expect a soft top line environment to persist in the second quarter, partially due to Exelis' relatively strong prior year and December results, we're encouraged by the orders rebound in the first quarter. Momentum for U.S. tactical modernization is building, and the recent SOCOM award on top of the early awards that the radio and the midtier radio are a testament to the strength of Harris' commercial model and the positive return on our sustained investments on R&D through the market downturn. 
And with that, I'd like to ask the operator to open the lines for questions.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Peter Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Peter Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the book-to-bill of 1.24, I know it's one of your your strongest quarter ever, is this SOCOM SEC, is that whingeing there in the orders because of the protest, it is not in there?
componenttext: On the book-to-bill of 1.24, I know it's one of your your strongest quarter ever, is this SOCOM SEC, is that whingeing there in the orders because of the protest, it is not in there?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it's not because of the protest either, but SOCOM is not in here, but it would be an IDIQ, so we would not be booking that as a funded order. Basically, the strength principally comes from very strong results in our tactical radio businesses, I mentio
componenttext: No, it's not because of the protest either, but SOCOM is not in here, but it would be an IDIQ, so we would not be booking that as a funded order. Basically, the strength principally comes from very strong results in our tactical radio businesses, I mentioned up 30%, and pretty broad-based across both the DoD as well as international side. We saw very good orders growth in electronic warfare, in space superiority in our proprietary business in a couple of other areas and that's really what drives a big strong orders growth in the quarter.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. That's great. And then, Bill, can you give us like you have in the past the size of the international radio pipeline?
componenttext: Okay, that's great. That's great. And then, Bill, can you give us like you have in the past the size of the international radio pipeline?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the international pipeline remains pretty robust, and I'm very pleased with that, so $2.4 billion. The shape moves around a little bit but not a whole lot. It's been fluctuating between $2.4 billion and $2.5 billion over the last number of quarters.
componenttext: Yes, the international pipeline remains pretty robust, and I'm very pleased with that, so $2.4 billion. The shape moves around a little bit but not a whole lot. It's been fluctuating between $2.4 billion and $2.5 billion over the last number of quarters. But given our very strong order growth in Q4, remember, orders are up 73%, book-to-bill was 1.1 which was very, very pleasing to end Q4, we had another strong order growth in Q1, so the pipeline remains pretty robust at $2.4 billion. And again, it's like the comments I made before in terms of its shape, it's primarily little more than half Middle East, North Africa, Central Asia, a couple of other areas that we saw very, very good growth. And in fact, the orders growth in the quarter, as I mentioned in my comments, were pretty broad-based across the geographies outside the U.S.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Seth Sackman of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Seth Sackman of JPMorgan.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to go back to one of the last comments that you made about the second quarter, and I know you might want to shy away from giving quarterly guidance. But just in terms of the guidance for the year, 22 -- roughly a little over 20% of the reven
componenttext: I just wanted to go back to one of the last comments that you made about the second quarter, and I know you might want to shy away from giving quarterly guidance. But just in terms of the guidance for the year, 22 -- roughly a little over 20% of the revenue in Q1. It sounds like it's a little bit more back-end weighted, whereas last year about half of sales for the combined company were in the first half. If you could talk a little bit about your level of visibility and level of confidence in the second half sales pickup?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we feel -- you're right in those comments. We do think it's more back-half than front-half loaded. That's to be be built our plan for the year, so it's not surprising we had -- we're little light in Q1, down 6% organically. We know that bringing the E
componenttext: No, we feel -- you're right in those comments. We do think it's more back-half than front-half loaded. That's to be be built our plan for the year, so it's not surprising we had -- we're little light in Q1, down 6% organically. We know that bringing the Exelis into our business, we showed our numbers on a pro forma basis. They had a fiscal year last year, which ended in December, so their fourth quarter was now our second quarter. They had a pretty strong run at that quarter as a lot of companies do in the last quarter of their fiscal year, so that does give us some year-over-year headwind. And keep in mind, we're still under a continuing the resolution. There's no appropriations budgets yet, and that still does drive some stickiness in the planning outlays for what is now our second quarter. We do expect given the budget deal and more favorable comparisons to see a recovery in the back half of our fiscal year.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just as a follow-up, I wonder if you could talk about trends in the Critical Networks business. I mean, that's one business where it seems like the sales that you booked in the first quarter are kind of on par with kind of the run rate tha
componenttext: Great. And then just as a follow-up, I wonder if you could talk about trends in the Critical Networks business. I mean, that's one business where it seems like the sales that you booked in the first quarter are kind of on par with kind of the run rate that you're looking for through the year and kind of -- are things kind of stabilizing there? I know there's 2 markets there where there's a couple of challenges in the government services and in energy and kind of what the latest there?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's been it's a business that has -- came out of the gates a little soft. We're guiding down 10% to 12% for the full year. Q1 was down 12%. Very pleased that we're protecting the margins. I think we're doing a good job in taking cost out in spite of
componenttext: Yes, it's been it's a business that has -- came out of the gates a little soft. We're guiding down 10% to 12% for the full year. Q1 was down 12%. Very pleased that we're protecting the margins. I think we're doing a good job in taking cost out in spite of the pretty weak revenue environment. But you hit the nail on the head. It's 2 soft markets. One is government IT that we see down in the mid-teens for the year, not different than what we talked about last time as if both IR, IT Services business as well as the Exelis IT business. Q1 was a bit down worse than that in Government IT Services, but we do expect that the revenue will be roughly flat sequentially over the balance of the year. The book-to-bill in Q1 was about -- was over 1. We expect it to be about 1 for the year, so that feels pretty good. Keep in mind, in IT Services, we had a couple of unique dimensions happening here. one, Exelis lost the space launch range system contract prior to the acquisition, happened just over a year ago, and that's rolling through the numbers. That's about $85 million. there's a couple of other programs that we are transitioning out of Harris, specifically the NMCI contract and a pretty large VA program that ended last year. So there's a couple of different things, dynamics that are happening that are relatively unique in the Government IT market for us. We are refocusing on the intelligence community. We think that there's an opportunity to differentiate ourselves in that space. Some of those awards are moving a little bit to the right, but I think that's going to start to see some stability with a balance of the year as at least in terms of sequential growth. The other one that has an impact in the quarter is that you suggested is that in the CapRock energy business. We expected that to be weak in the year. It's going to be down on a full year basis, sort of no mid-teens in Q1, it was a little bit worse than that. We know that oil is still relatively weak. We saw the results from a lot of the oil service companies and majors over the last quarter. Rig count remains pretty weak. It's down about 40% year-over-year. And some of the oil majors and service companies are announcing more restructurings and CapEx cuts, so we do see continued pressure on that business. We're watching it very, very carefully. We think we calibrated our year, but again, the market is pretty volatile at this point. We keep watching it. The piece in that Critical Networks, it is relatively stable. We feel good about that on the FAA side. We've got a good portfolio businesses with the FAA. It's pretty broad based, and we feel very good about our position and the funding pattern for the FA program within cargo networks. so soft, when you put all the pieces together long-winded way of saying that's what the network is down about 10% to 12% in the year.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015

componenttext: Maybe just first one on margins. If I'm bringing the slides correctly and we're looking at pro forma margins in the segments, you had big step-ups in 3 out of the 4 segments. Are there anything to read across from that in terms of how they phase through the year? Or this is just a seasonally strong quarter for margins?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we typically see seasonal strength in Q1. It moves based on things going on in the business quarter-to-quarter. But we -- I would say we do expect to see synergy savings ramping over the balance of the year. I mentioned in my comments with $11 milli
componenttext: Well, we typically see seasonal strength in Q1. It moves based on things going on in the business quarter-to-quarter. But we -- I would say we do expect to see synergy savings ramping over the balance of the year. I mentioned in my comments with $11 million in Q1. Sheldon talked about $70 million to $75 million in full year, so of course, that is going to happen. The bulk of that, that's yet to come in not in our numbers, so you will see some strength coming in the numbers simply because of integration savings, which are booked within the segments. The other side is we are pushing very, very hard in our legacy operational excellence, Harris business excellence program, and we do see opportunities to continue to protect margins in each of the segments because of that. So 3 of the segments very strong margin expansion, one that we feel pretty good about holding margins in spite of a pretty significant revenue downturn. So I think from Harris, I think good control in our cost structure so far.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then second question maybe on a couple of the big program. I was wondering if you could give us maybe what your view is on the Manpack contract as to how you see that field laying out. Do you think like Riflemen, it'll be your selves versus a c
componenttext: Great. And then second question maybe on a couple of the big program. I was wondering if you could give us maybe what your view is on the Manpack contract as to how you see that field laying out. Do you think like Riflemen, it'll be your selves versus a competitive field of additional one or could perhaps be more than one? And then what you been able to do on the domestic programs? Do you see a big opportunity to change the scope and direction of the U.K. replacement? And is that a major opportunity going forward if you can get them to think outside of their current provider.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first, on the first one on the Manpack, it's [indiscernible] so it's still in source selection process, so I really don't have insights into whilst it's been coming on the table more than what has been rumored in the press. As I mentioned in prior c
componenttext: Well, first, on the first one on the Manpack, it's [indiscernible] so it's still in source selection process, so I really don't have insights into whilst it's been coming on the table more than what has been rumored in the press. As I mentioned in prior comments, the Army does expect to issue an award, could be early December. We're thinking more it's early next calendar year depends upon who comes at the table. They're expecting to issue up to 3 IDIQ awardees and then as what we see at this point. We do know that it's going to be a very large $12 billion-plus ceiling value IDIQ, and I think we're very, very well positioned for that. So I feel very good about where we happen to be on the Manpack and not much more to say at this point given the status of that opportunity. Relative to Bowman or that would be a pretty interesting opportunity for us. Exelis is an important player there as has Harris has been. So we together are more affordable player in the U.K. We have been working with other partners in the U.K. That's going to be shaking itself out over the next several years not several quarters. So I really don't want to say too much more about how we might position ourselves for success in the U.K., but Steven, [indiscernible] is Head of our Global Business Development Group and tactical radios that we do today is leading our global organization and I can assure you he's focused on the U.K.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gautam Khanna with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gautam Khanna with Cowen and Company.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, can you quantify the run rate eventually on programs like MNVR, the Riflemen program and Manpack as far as you can tell, I mean, if there are eventually 2 awardees on that? I mean, what is sort of the run rate? I know what the budgeted dollars are,
componenttext: Bill, can you quantify the run rate eventually on programs like MNVR, the Riflemen program and Manpack as far as you can tell, I mean, if there are eventually 2 awardees on that? I mean, what is sort of the run rate? I know what the budgeted dollars are, but what you actually anticipate these to mature run rate to be?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's really hard to put a number of outside what's in PBR, Gautam, to be honest with you. I'd be speculating and I hate to do on these kinds of calls, so I won't. As we said before, MNVR last year was sort of $8 million to $10 million, $12 billion of reve
componenttext: It's really hard to put a number of outside what's in PBR, Gautam, to be honest with you. I'd be speculating and I hate to do on these kinds of calls, so I won't. As we said before, MNVR last year was sort of $8 million to $10 million, $12 billion of revenues. This year, it'll be twice that, $20 million to $25 million. We see that could grow to $40 million to $45 million, again depends upon its what the Army wants to do and how they're going to get the radio in, their BCT structure and all sorts of other dynamics that come into play. We do know that between the Riflemen and the Manpack, that, we've been told, could be a procurement up to about $0.5 billion a year. If you look at the PVR, that's what it says. We don't have any more insights relative to the total market opportunity for us. What our job is to do is put forth our most aggressive approach, a fantastic technological advanced and innovative product, and we're 100% sure that business whatever happens to be and that's what we're focused on.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you comment on what the riflemen is running at in the current fiscal year?
componenttext: Can you comment on what the riflemen is running at in the current fiscal year?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, riflemen won't be any revenue this year or next. It will start to ramp -- at the end of fiscal '17 is when the riflemen will start to ramp. It's probably the second half of our fiscal '17 and will become a little bit more meaningful in fiscal '18.
componenttext: Well, riflemen won't be any revenue this year or next. It will start to ramp -- at the end of fiscal '17 is when the riflemen will start to ramp. It's probably the second half of our fiscal '17 and will become a little bit more meaningful in fiscal '18.

componenttext: Yes, thank you very much. And I think as we said, there've been multiple actions taken the past from -- in 2011 freezing new hires and lump sums like Middle East given out. And yes, we closed the benefit in the year 2016. So moving forward, we see -- we're definitely trying to address the asset side and the liability side. On the liabilities, we're considering some cash balance for the the active, so perhaps some lump sum for some of the invested in place to take advantage of the IRS rulings. And so far as moving forward to matching our assets to the obligations longevity so we'll derisk to the final glidepath and with specific trigger points.

componenttext: We see a modest reduction in cash contributions going to next fiscal year, fiscal '17, sort of in the $170 million range. But we do see '19, '20 down could be quite less than that, so in the fiscal '19. So something like 3 years out, fiscal '18, hitting $1 billion, hitting that $1 billion of free cash flow, target 3 years out, does not include really any reductions in pension contribution. It really happens beyond the horizon.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015

componenttext: Got it. Okay, one last one. On the foreign pipeline, $54.4 billion [ph] are you anticipating any significant single contract awards from that? Or is it a fairly lumpy thing? Or is it diverse across many smaller opportunities, if you could just give us a sense of what we should be expecting like a huge Australian win or huge Saudi win. What shall we be looking for?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: There are certain markets and there are a couple that are quite large in a longer pipeline, and we do see our position in Australia as strong. There's a procurement on horizon that goes out beyond 18 months that is quite substantial, and we're in a midst
componenttext: There are certain markets and there are a couple that are quite large in a longer pipeline, and we do see our position in Australia as strong. There's a procurement on horizon that goes out beyond 18 months that is quite substantial, and we're in a midst of that but it's not in the 12- to 18-month length. It really is pretty broad based. It's across a lot of different markets through the Middle East, through north Africa, into Central Asia. It was very, very good to see FMS funding through OCO accounts continuing to bolster what's happening in Iraq through the train and equip funds, through ERI which flow through into some opportunities in the Baltics. We saw some good opportunity surface in Latin America this past quarter, and they're still in our pipeline. So it is pretty broad based. There's not any big substantial orders that are in our 12- to 18-month horizon that I'd want to single out. Beyond that, there are some big opportunities in markets like in Saudi as well as in Australia, but nothing that's gigantic in the next 18 months.

componenttext: Let me -- Chris, hey, thanks for the question, Chris,  I'll take the first and maybe turn to Sheldon on the second, he you can elaborate a little bit. The downturn of space payloads really is more legacy Harrison than legacy Exelis. Remember, couple of years ago, we booked an opportunity with Aireon for putting those to payload on a Iridium NEXT constellation. That work has been through the pipeline. We're delivering vehicles. We're pretty far down the path of recognizing revenue and opportunity and that's start to move back off. So that's more on the legacy Harris than legacy Exelis perspective. Let me turn to Sheldon maybe to give couple of comments on outlook for Space Imaging.

componenttext: Yes. Chris, the outlook up in Rochester for Exelis' legacy imaging business is actually very strong. It had an upturn in the number of new orders in new programs. They're hiring up here in Rochester, and they've developed signing new technologies that we believe have allocation both in traditional markets basis and in this new emerging commercial market imaging space. So we're very bullish on their imaging business in Rochester.

componenttext: Well, certainly this year is going to be pretty solid and it's going to be a driver of growth in '16 over '15. It remains to be seen what happens beyond '16. headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's actually from [indiscernible] so we were curious actually on how you see the new budget deal helping short-cycle defense, if you could give us a little bit of color in that?
componenttext: It's actually from [indiscernible] so we were curious actually on how you see the new budget deal helping short-cycle defense, if you could give us a little bit of color in that?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, look, the 2-year deal is pretty encouraging to us. It's encouraging to the rest of the industry. It's going to eliminate some of the overhang of uncertainty, and all that I think is good news. I think you know the budget like we do. DoD is a 5% fisc
componenttext: Well, look, the 2-year deal is pretty encouraging to us. It's encouraging to the rest of the industry. It's going to eliminate some of the overhang of uncertainty, and all that I think is good news. I think you know the budget like we do. DoD is a 5% fiscal '16, maybe another 2% in '17, so that's pretty good. We were very pleased with the size of the OCO accounts because some of the funding that we used for international comes out of OCO accounts like [indiscernible] and in a couple of counterterrorism partnerships other thing that will help us definitely in '16 and going forward into '17. But look, it's a deal. There's no appropriations bills yet. That needs to flow itself out. That will happen between now and, hopefully, December 11. But judging by what lies in the NDAA that was, unfortunately, vetoed by the President but it's going to flow back through, I think a lot of the Harris program seem to be well supported both in the tactical, normal tactical lines as well as in other things that affect Harris Corporation. So I do think that the budget deals and the certainty and the level of funding is going to be good news for Harrisburg short-cycle and medium-cycle opportunities as well as the rest of the industry. So I think net-net, it's just good news.

componenttext: Okay, great, great. And I guess if I can sneak in a last last one on the legacy product lines. headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, I won't give color so deep into the businesses at that level, but I would say that on a night vision side, 5 years ago, it was quite big based on where the -- both happening in the wars. It's come down. It is starting to bottom out and flatten out a
componenttext: Look, I won't give color so deep into the businesses at that level, but I would say that on a night vision side, 5 years ago, it was quite big based on where the -- both happening in the wars. It's come down. It is starting to bottom out and flatten out and we are doing I think an outstanding job in our Roanoke facility to improve quality and the delivery schedule with the Army, within credibility. I think we're doing a very, very good job and I do see stability in that business. What Sheldon mentioned in his remarks on the Exelis side with a very large installed base is SINCGARS radios in the U.S. and outside the U.S. and, in fact, lots of countries that have standardized on SINCGARS and will continue to buy that. So we do expect to see growth opportunities in SINCGARS, and hopefully, we can leverage more of the existing Harris channels to open up some new opportunities that haven't been there before. So I wouldn't give anymore color than that. There has been some downturns in that night vision comp systems business, but we feel pretty good about the prospects going forward.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, there is some -- we do see price pressure all the time in our international business because it's very competitive, and that has been the case when we continue to deal with a lot of cost reductions and bringing technology. We sell our product in doll
componenttext: Yes, there is some -- we do see price pressure all the time in our international business because it's very competitive, and that has been the case when we continue to deal with a lot of cost reductions and bringing technology. We sell our product in dollars, and it does cause some headwind with non-U.S. providers, some competitive pressure, but we respond aggressively to that. On the other commodity side, which is on the oil side, we have seen some stretch out in a couple of markets. We talked about this last time. That remains the case today in Iraq and in Saudi. Where we have seen some stretch out in some of the opportunities that's factored in our pipeline, it's factored in our guidance for the year. We do now that in Saudi, there are -- they have prioritized investments for their military further combat the orders strike with Yemen. But again, those things have already factored into our guidance.
